{{Distinguish|Clash of the Titans (video game)}} {{Infobox video game | title = Crash of the Titans | image = Crash of the Titans cover.jpg | caption = Cover art depicting Crash jacking a Ratcicle | developer = [[Radical Entertainment]] (PS2, PSP, Xbox 360, & Wii)
[[SuperVillain Studios]] (PSP)
[[Amaze Entertainment]] (GBA & NDS) | publisher = [[Vivendi Games]]{{efn|Released under the [[Sierra Entertainment]] brand name}} | designer = Joe McGinn | programmer = Ryan Ridout
Ian Gipson | writer = Chris Mitchell | artist = Yousuf Mapara | composer = [[Marc Baril]] (home console)
Nathaniel Papadakis (handheld) | series = ''[[Crash Bandicoot (series)|Crash Bandicoot]]'' | released = '''PlayStation 2''', '''Xbox 360''' & '''Game Boy Advance'''
{{vgrelease|NA|October 4, 2007{{cite web|title=''Crash of the Titans'' (Wii) at GameSpot |url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/action/crashofthetitans/index.html |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=2007-07-13}}|EU|October 12, 2007{{cite web|date=2007-04-19 |last=Harris |first=Craig |title=IGN: ''Crash of the Titans'' Preview |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/782/782068p1.html |publisher=IGN |accessdate=2008-07-08}}|AUS|October 18, 2007}}'''Wii'''
{{vgrelease|NA|October 4, 2007|EU|October 12, 2007|AUS|October 23, 2007}}'''PlayStation Portable'''
{{vgrelease|NA|October 16, 2007|AUS|November 22, 2007}}{{vgrelease|EU|November 23, 2007}}'''Nintendo DS'''
{{vgrelease|EU|October 19, 2007|AUS|October 23, 2007}}{{vgrelease|NA|October 25, 2007}} | genre = [[Platform game|Platform]], [[beat 'em up]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Game Boy Advance]], [[Wii]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[Nintendo DS]] }} '''''Crash of the Titans''''' is a [[platform game]] developed by [[Radical Entertainment]] and published by [[Vivendi Games]] for the [[PlayStation 2]], [[PlayStation Portable]] ([[Porting|ported]] by [[SuperVillain Studios]]), [[Wii]] and [[Xbox 360]]. The [[Game Boy Advance]] and [[Nintendo DS]] versions of the game were developed by [[Amaze Entertainment]]. The game was first released in North America on October 3, 2007, in Europe on October 12, 2007 and in Australia on October 25, 2007. It is the first game in the ''[[Crash Bandicoot (series)|Crash Bandicoot]]'' series not to have a Japanese release. ''Crash of the Titans'' is the fourteenth installment in the ''Crash Bandicoot'' video game series, the sixth game in the main franchise, and the first in the ''Mutant'' subseries. The game's story centers on the discovery of a substance known as "Mojo", which the antagonist of the series, [[Doctor Neo Cortex]], plans to use to turn the inhabitants of the Wumpa Islands into an army of loyal mutants known as "Titans". The protagonist of the series, [[Crash Bandicoot (character)|Crash Bandicoot]], must stop Cortex by using the technique of "jacking" to take control of and destroy Cortex's Titans while collecting the mojo. The game received mixed reviews upon its release, while the DS version received favourable reception. Critics disparaged the game's short length, and although the game's variety was generally seen positively, reviewers noted little outstanding in the game. Despite this mediocre reception, the game was nominated for two awards. ==Gameplay== ''Crash of the Titans'' is a beat-em-up game with platforming aspects in which the player controls [[Crash Bandicoot (character)|Crash Bandicoot]], whose main objective is to rescue his sister, [[Coco Bandicoot|Coco]], and save his home, the Wumpa Island, from being destroyed by the main antagonist's gigantic robot.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=4 |chapter=How to Play }} The player's first goal is to rescue the sentient mask [[Aku Aku (character)|Aku Aku]], who gives the player basic instructions, shields Crash from enemy attacks, and transforms into a skateboard to help Crash traverse slippery terrain. From there, each [[Level (video gaming)|level]] (known as an "episode") asks players to complete fights against large groups of enemies or simply progress through the episode. Crash starts the game with four [[Health (game mechanic)#Icon-based|lives]]. The length of each of Crash's lives is tied to his [[Health (gaming)|health meter]], which decreases whenever Crash is damaged from enemy attacks or falls down a bottomless pit.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |editor= |others= |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii) |date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |page=5 |chapter=The Game Screen}} The player can replenish Crash's health meter by instructing Crash to eat Wumpa Fruit. Each time the health meter is fully depleted, Crash loses a life. However, the player can win an additional life for Crash by collecting 25,000 units of the magical substance Mojo{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii) |date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |page=6 |chapter=Upgrades}} or by collecting a rare type of Golden Wumpa Fruit.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |editor= |others= |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |page=6 |chapter=Power-Ups }} After the last life is lost, the player can continue playing by restarting the current episode. Each episode contains a portal leading to a simple mini-game arena, where the player must accomplish a task in a set time. Generally the task involves collecting a specified quantity of Mojo, using an enemy animal's attacks to snipe targets, or simply defeating a select number of enemies.{{cite web |last=Lewis |first=Cameron |date=2007-10-04 |publisher=[[GameSpy]] |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (PlayStation 2: 2007) |url=http://uk.ps2.gamespy.com/playstation-2/crash-of-the-titans/825058p1.html |accessdate=2007-10-05}} At the end of each episode, the player earns a rank of a bronze, silver, or gold voodoo doll;{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |editor= |others= |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii) |date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=5 |chapter=The End Level Screen }} the rank can be improved by defeating a set number of minions, destroying three robotic toilets or inflicting a minimum number of consecutive hits in combat. All three tasks must be accomplished in an episode if a gold voodoo doll is to be obtained for that episode. Hidden voodoo dolls unlock concept art packages for each episode.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |editor= |others= |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=6 |chapter=Other Rewards }} The Nintendo DS version of ''Crash of the Titans'' contains similar gameplay to that of previous ''Crash'' installments. The game takes place on four islands, each with two [[Level (video gaming)|levels]] and a [[Boss (video gaming)|boss]]. When a boss is defeated, a new island is unlocked.{{cite web|publisher=Crash Mania |author=JumpButton |date=2007-07-12 |title=Crash Mania official interview with Amaze Entertainment |url=http://hpzr.freeweb7.com/interviewamaze.htm |accessdate=2007-07-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070929103134/http://hpzr.freeweb7.com/interviewamaze.htm |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }} Each island has its own "[[Pachinko]] board" where players can win "on-demand items"; items that can be used to restore health, provide temporary invincibility, and set off Nitro explosions among other things. Additional content can also be won at these Pachinko boards, such as gallery art, cheats and a large quantity of Mojo. ===Combat=== [[Image:Spikeparafox.jpg|thumb|left|Crash Bandicoot and "Carbon Crash" have jacked the Titans Snipe and Spike, respectively]] Whereas the previous games featured Crash spinning into or jumping on an enemy to attack, ''Crash of the Titans'' gives him more options for attack. Early in the game, Crash has a light-powered attack and a heavy-powered attack and can also block, dodge or break an enemy's block.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |editor= |others= |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=7 |chapter=How to be a Great Fighter }} When he defeats an enemy or destroys an object, a magical substance known as Mojo is released. When Crash collects enough Mojo, he will earn either an ability upgrade or a new move, such as the [[Chuck Norris|Norris]] Roundhouse or the Triple Dragon. His classic spin attack, named "Old Skool", is an unlockable move, along with an aerial variant that allows Crash to float over chasms.{{cite web |date=2007-04-20 |publisher=GameSpot |last=Shoemaker |first=Brad |title=''Crash of the Titans'' First Look |url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/action/crashofthetitans/news.html?sid=6169477&om_act=convert&om_clk=newsfeatures&tag=newsfeatures;title;1 |accessdate=2008-05-10}} While small minions require only a single [[Combo (gaming)|combo attack]] for Crash to defeat, larger enemies, known as "Titans", require more effort to subdue. Each of the fifteen unique Titans in the game possess a star meter that indicates how close they are to being stunned.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |editor= |others= |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |page=6 |chapter=How to Jack an Enemy }} The meter rises when Crash starts attacking a Titan, and depletes when he stops. When it is full, the Titan is stunned and susceptible to "jacking", meaning Crash can mount the creature and control it. While controlled by the player, the Titan possesses a similar moveset to Crash, although some jacked Titans can shoot projectiles.{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=7 |chapter=Controlling Enemies }} Besides a greater health, the Titans controlled by Crash have a purple Titan Meter. When this meter is full, players can make the Titan unleash a special attack, which fully drains the meter in the process. A Titan's durability depends on its size; larger Titans will take more effort to defeat than others and a few are immune to Crash's attacks. To defeat them, Crash has to jack a smaller Titan to fight them. On defeating the larger Titan, he can dismount the Titan he previously jacked and directly jack the larger Titan. The dismounted Titan will then be destroyed. ===Co-operative play=== A player using a second controller can join the game at any time in the form of a white-furred version of Crash known as "Carbon Crash".{{cite book |author=Radical Entertainment |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Wii)|date=2007-10-04 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=8 |chapter=Multiplayer Co-op Mode }} The second player appears in the first player's backpack, and can usually enter or exit the pack. However, the second player has to stay in the backpack if the first player is in mid-air or climbing a wall. This method of play is useful for overpowering enemies and collecting Mojo faster. There are two modes of co-op play; in "Leapfrog Mode", the players swap control each time the front player jumps, swings, or slides, while in "Piggyback Mode", each player is equipped with their own backpack and can hide in the other player's backpack if the action becomes too intense, such as when jumping over a chasm. ==Plot== ===Setting=== The setting of ''Crash of the Titans'' features twenty levels. Each level is referred to as an "episode", and each has a distinctive subtitle that is usually a reference to popular culture (such as "[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Blizzard of Claws]]"). Like the first ''[[Crash Bandicoot (video game)|Crash Bandicoot]]'' game, episodes must be played in order, although the player can replay any episode that has been completed. The game moves through five major themes taking place on Crash's homeland, the Wumpa Islands. The story starts in the jungle near Crash's residence and leads to an ancient temple. Later in the game, Crash travels through a wood-cutting and mining area and a land flowing with lava that features giant steel mosquitoes sucking minerals out of the ground. The next few episodes take place on an artillery-bombarded beach, where Crash infiltrates [[Doctor N. Gin]]'s missile factory, which resembles the [[Statue of Liberty]]. The penultimate area is a gigantic tree located in the middle of the island. This tree holds up an entire house owned by Uka Uka, one of the major antagonists of the series. The final moments of the game take place in the antagonist's [[Liberace]]-style lair, and finally inside the Doominator. ===Characters=== {{main article|Characters of Crash Bandicoot}} [[Image:TitansCast.PNG|thumb|The main cast of ''Crash of the Titans'' sporting their new "punk" look]] Nine characters from previous ''Crash Bandicoot'' titles star in the home console version of ''Crash of the Titans'',{{cite web |date=2007-04-19 |publisher=IGN |title=IGN character sheet |url=http://media.wii.ign.com/media/899/899066/img_4483484.html |accessdate=2007-07-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070529135749/http://media.wii.ign.com/media/899/899066/img_4483484.html |archivedate=2007-05-29 |df= }} all of them given a new modern "punk" style that is distinct from other and Japanese video game characters.{{cite web|publisher=Crash Mania |author=JumpButton |date=2007-04-24 |title=Crash Mania official interview with Radical Entertainment |url=http://hpzr.freeweb7.com/interviewtitans.htm |accessdate=2007-07-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070929120042/http://hpzr.freeweb7.com/interviewtitans.htm |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }} The protagonist of the game, Crash Bandicoot, is a [[bandicoot]] who must defeat the main antagonist [[Doctor Neo Cortex]] and use the Titans against each other while collecting Mojo to upgrade his fighting techniques. Aiding Crash is [[Aku Aku (character)|Aku Aku]], an ancient wooden mask who acts as a shield, a skateboard, and a weapon. He can also help Crash jack Titans. Crash's other two allies are his genius sister [[Coco Bandicoot]] and his muscular older brother, [[Crunch Bandicoot]], who is absent in the Nintendo DS version. Doctor Neo Cortex is a [[mad scientist]] who captures Coco and Aku Aku and wants to use stolen Mojo to create an army of mutants. [[Uka Uka]], who is also absent in the Nintendo DS version, is behind Cortex's plot for world domination; after tiring of Cortex's incompetence, Uka replaces him with his cyborg niece, [[Nina Cortex]]. Aiding the Cortexes are [[Doctor N. Gin]], who is Cortex's hysterical right-hand man, and Tiny Tiger. [[Dingodile]], another minion of Cortex, exclusively appears in the DS and Game Boy Advance versions of ''Crash of the Titans'' as a boss character. Aiding the villains are a number of small fodder enemies that attempt to hinder Crash in his journey. Each fodder is affiliated with a certain villain in the game. The first fodders encountered are Neo Cortex's Ratnicians, which appear as bipedal, chihuahua-like animals dressed as laboratory researchers. These characters appear in the first four episodes of the game, and are replaced by other enemies as the game progresses. The later enemies include Tiny Tiger's Southern-accented Koo-alas, Doctor N. Gin's monkey wrench-wielding Doom Monkeys, Uka Uka's spear-chucking Voodoo Bunnies, and Nina Cortex's Brat Girls. [[Radical Entertainment]] sought to give these minor characters personalities by giving them a large number of distinctive quotations. ===Story=== In the beginning of the game, Crash Bandicoot aids Coco with a butter-recycling device.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 1: A New Hop |quote='''Coco Bandicoot:''' Crash! Help me get this gizmo working! At long last, the world will have a way to recycle butter!}} Doctor Neo Cortex arrives, captures Aku Aku and Coco and encases Crunch in ice. Crash throws Coco's machine at Cortex's airship, severing the chain holding Aku Aku's cage, which causes the cage to fall into the nearby forest. After Crash rescues Aku Aku, they discover that Cortex and Uka Uka are stealing Mojo from a nearby temple and decide to stop them.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 3: A Zero's Journey |quote='''Aku Aku:''' Crash, it's as I feared. Cortex and Uka Uka are stealing all the Mojo from the temple. This is somehow related to the strange mutants we've been fighting.}} On reaching the temple, Cortex reveals his plot to use the stolen Mojo to create an army of loyal mutants, which will be used to build a robot known as the Doominator, that will crush the Wumpa Islands and take over the world.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 4: The Temple of Zoom |quote='''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' I will use the stolen Mojo to create a huge army of loyal mutants! Not rejects, like you guys. / '''Coco Bandicoot:''' You jerk. / '''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' But best of all, I will use this army to construct a mighty robot, the largest doomsday device I've ever built. I will smash Wumpa Island, then take over the world! And I shall call this robot... the Doominator!!}} After failing to defeat Crash with his Yuktopus cyborg, Cortex boasts that Crash will never find his base and flies off, leaving Crash and Aku Aku to follow him.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 4: The Temple of Zoom |quote='''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' You think you've won, you furry simpleton? Well, Uka Uka got away with the Mojo and your sister! You'll never find them in time. The next time you see me, Crash, I will be controlling a world-conquering robot!}} At Cortex's base, Uka Uka derides Cortex for failing to destroy Crash and replaces Cortex with his niece, Nina Cortex, despite protests from Neo, N. Gin and Tiny Tiger.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 4: The Temple of Zoom |quote='''Uka Uka:''' That was ridiculous and appalling! You've failed to destroy Crash Bandicoot! / '''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' I don't see what the big deal is. We got away with the Mojo and Crash's sister! / '''Uka Uka:''' ''I'' got away with the Mojo, and the big deal is that Crash Bandicoot is still alive! Cortex, I am going to replace you. ''(Shocked, Neo Cortex spits his tea all over N. Gin's face. N. Gin screams in pain)'' / '''Doctor N. Gin:''' Thank you, master! / '''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' You can't replace me. My name's on the stationery! / '''Doctor N. Gin:''' ''(giggles)'' That's right, tough guy! Unless you want to buy a new stationery, you respect the master!! / '''Tiny Tiger:''' It's really nice stationery, too. / '''Doctor N. Gin:''' Oh, I know! Glossy!}} Nina has Coco brainwashed and makes her participate in the construction of the Doominator.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 4: The Temple of Zoom |quote='''Nina Cortex:''' Sorry, uncle, but it's time for some young blood to lead us to victory. And now that we have Coco, we can make her build the robot. / '''Coco Bandicoot:''' You won't get away with this! Crash will come for me and kick your butt! / '''Nina Cortex:''' Oh, I hope Crash tries, I really do. After all, I need a new fur coat. ''(Nina laughs)'' Get to work on the Doominator! Make more mutant soldiers! I want Wumpa Island smashed flat. / '''Coco Bandicoot:''' Your... hair is dumb! / '''Nina Cortex:''' Oh, shut her up. ''(A brainwashing helmet falls out of nowhere onto Coco's head.)''}} Throughout the course of the game, Crash and Aku Aku interrogate Tiny Tiger,{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 7: The Blizzard of Claws |quote='''Tiny Tiger:''' I'll tell you where they go! Nina took Coco to the factory on the beach. / '''Crash Bandicoot:''' Nina? Howjibeduvuh? / '''Aku Aku:''' Nina? You mean Doctor Cortex, don't you? / '''Tiny Tiger:''' No! Nina! Uka Uka and her got rid of Cortex. They were tired of Cortex failing all the time.}} Doctor N. Gin{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 13: Doomraker |quote='''Doctor N. Gin:''' That's right, stupids! You need to go to Uka Uka's lab and stop him! That's where they make all the delicious mutants! Maybe your revolting sister is there, too. Eugh... girls...}} and Uka Uka on the whereabouts of Coco.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 17: Adolt Edumacation |quote='''Uka Uka:''' You think you've defeated me? I'll get the last laugh on you fools! Any moment now, Nina will launch the robot, and Wumpa Island will be doomed! / '''Aku Aku:''' You monster! / '''Uka Uka:''' And Nina will have no more use for your lovely sister, so she's finished, too! I get the last laugh! ''(laughs)'' I'm laughing now, too, just in case.}} When they confront Nina Cortex inside the Doominator robot, Nina summons her Arachnina cyborg and fights Crash.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 20: Revengeance 2: The Revengicide |quote='''Nina Cortex:''' I really didn't wanted do this myself. I really wanted one of my idiot underlings to destroy you! I really didn't wanted get hair all over my clothes!! But if you want something done right... use a giant spiderbot!!}} Crash eventually destroys the robot, liberating Coco and disabling the Doominator. The Doominator collapses and barely misses the Bandicoot home (and Crunch), sparing much of Wumpa Island. Escaping from the collapsed Doominator, Cortex praises Nina for betraying him, and promises to be more evil in the near future.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 20: Revengeance 2 The Revengicide |quote=Why did you rescue me? I betrayed you, took over your evil plan... then failed. / '''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' Oh, Nina. Betraying me is the most vile, evil thing you could've ever done! You're a skank. I'm... just so proud of you right now. / '''Nina Cortex:''' Hooray! / '''Doctor Neo Cortex:''' I promise. From now on, I'll be more evil, more villainous, more horrible! Horrible! Oh, and go kill bandicoots too. I'm still going to spank you stupid for this. / '''Nina Cortex:''' Ohhh...}} The Bandicoots decide that it is time for celebration, leading Crash to shout his first word in the series and the object of their celebration: pancakes.{{cite video game |title=Crash of the Titans |developer=Radical Entertainment |publisher=Sierra Entertainment |date=2007-10-04 |platform=Wii |level=Episode 20: Revengeance 2 The Revengicide |quote='''Coco Bandicoot:''' Now let's go home... and eat pancakes! / '''Crash Bandicoot:''' ''(overjoyed)'' Pancakes!!}} The DS version of the game largely follows the story of the home console versions, but with minor alterations such as Nina Cortex having a greater role and the inclusion of [[Major characters of Crash Bandicoot#Dingodile|Dingodile]]. Near the end of the game, Nina teams up with Crash to stop Doctor Cortex and his dancing "CortexBot". The Game Boy Advance version also includes Dingodile, some plot differences, such as the Arachnina (referred to by its old name, "Spiderbot") not being the last boss, and Cortex being reinstated after Nina's defeat in the N. Trapment Island. ==Development== Development on ''Crash of the Titans'' began after the completion of ''[[Crash Tag Team Racing]]''. The graphics of the [[Wii]] version of the game was one of [[Radical Entertainment]]'s main focuses in the game's development, with Radical stating that the [[Wii]] has "a lot of horsepower under the hood" and expressing their desire to make full use of it.{{cite web |publisher=Codename Revolution |date=2007-03-02 |title=Wii has a lot of Horsepower says Radical |url=http://www.codenamerevolution.com/?p=4393 |accessdate=2007-07-13 |quote=The Wii has a lot of horsepower under the hood and we're making full use of it. We've overhauled our graphics engine to get the most out of the console by updating the shaders responsible for rendering the environment, vehicle, and characters. In many ways ''Scarface'' looks sharper on the Wii than it does on the PS2 and Xbox.}} They also considered implementing a feature to connect the Wii to DS during gameplay, but stopped due to technical issues and time. The [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation 2]] version got a few extra months of development time to improve its graphics before setting a final release date.{{cite web |publisher=Eurogamer |last=Reed |first=Kristan |date=2007-04-26 |title=Eurogamer's preview of ''Crash of the Titans'' |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=75703 |accessdate=2007-07-13}} While the game was being developed, the title's main character, Crash Bandicoot, became the new mascot of the [[Leukemia & Lymphoma Society]]'s "School and Youth" programs in an effort to promote the battle against blood cancer.{{cite web |publisher=GoNintendo |date=2007-08-06 |title=Video Game Hero Crash Bandicoot Urges Kids to Join the Fight Against Leukemia |url=http://gonintendo.com/?p=22481 |accessdate=2007-08-19 |quote=The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society and Vivendi Games today announced that Crash Bandicoot is and will always be a classic, the valiant, action hero of the highly popular video game series, is the new national champion for the Societyfs School & Youth programs.}} In a bid to further promote the game, a [[Hummer]] (with a Wii inside) was painted with imagery from the game and displayed at the Annual Balloon Fiesta in [[Bristol]], United Kingdom.{{cite web |last=De Marco |first=Flynn |date=2007-08-12 |publisher=Kotaku |title=''Crash of the Titans'': The Hummer |url=http://kotaku.com/gaming/beer-and-tractor-pulls/crash-of-the-titans-the-hummer-288623.php |accessdate=2007-08-19 |quote=Has spinners, the works. All with a Wii on the inside that people can play. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930224322/http://kotaku.com/gaming/beer-and-tractor-pulls/crash-of-the-titans-the-hummer-288623.php |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }} A "Monster Edition" of the game was released exclusively in Europe on October 12, 2007 for the PlayStation 2. This special edition of the game features "Making-of" videos, water-on tattoos, game hints, a cheat code list, and the game's E3 and theatrical trailers in multiple languages. Due to its "mild cartoon violence and language", the game received a PG rating from the [[British Board of Film Classification|BBFC]].{{cite web |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=2007-07-31 |title=''Crash of the Titans: Monster Edition'' rated PG by the BBFC |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/website/Classified.nsf/0/5710805319AAAE5080257329003EA50B?OpenDocument |accessdate=2007-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080106085324/http://www.bbfc.co.uk/website/Classified.nsf/0/5710805319AAAE5080257329003EA50B?OpenDocument |archivedate=2008-01-06 |df= }} ===Music=== Unlike ''[[Crash Tag Team Racing]]'', Radical did not hire the composer of the music in the previous ''Crash'' games, the [[a cappella]] band Spiralmouth whose members Rebecca Kneubuhl and Gabriel Mann left to compose musical pieces to ''[[The Legend of Spyro: The Eternal Night]]'' and ''[[The Legend of Spyro: Dawn of the Dragon]]'' from Crash's companion franchise ''[[Spyro the Dragon (series)|Spyro the Dragon]]'', to write the music for ''Crash of the Titans''. Instead, they assigned the job to their in-house composer Marc Baril, who took Spiralmouth's work on the previous games as references for ''Crash of the Titans''. Radical Entertainment has expressed its pride with some of the music featured in the game, such as Doctor N. Gin's [[polka]] theme. A 32-track soundtrack was made available on the [[iTunes Store#Music|iTunes Music Store]] on December 18, 2007.{{cite web |date=2007-12-18 |publisher=iTunes |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (Original Game Music Store) |url=http://phobos.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewAlbum?id=270102327&s=143441 |accessdate=2008-05-15}} The music in the Nintendo DS version of the game was created by Nathaniel Papadakis.{{cite book |author=Amaze Entertainment |title=Crash of the Titans American instruction manual (Nintendo DS) |year=2007 |publisher=Sierra Entertainment|page=8}} ===Voice cast=== To avoid repetitive audio, ''Crash of the Titans'' features more than 7,000 lines of dialogue,{{cite web |date=2007-07-12 |publisher=GameSpot |last=VanOrd |first=Kevin |title=E3 '07: ''Crash of the Titans'' Updated Impressions |url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/action/crashofthetitans/news.html?sid=6174788&om_act=convert&om_clk=newsfeatures&tag=newsfeatures;title;3 |accessdate=2008-05-10 |quote=It will feature more than 7,000 lines of dialogue from well-known voice actors, for starters, as well as the kind of silly humor you would expect from a Crash game.}} many of which contain references to popular culture, such as the film ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]''. To achieve a natural feel for their dialogue, the voice actors performed all their lines three times.{{cite web |publisher=Kidzworld |title=Making ''Crash of the Titans'' :: Inside Radical Entertainment (pg.2) |url=http://www.kidzworld.com/article/10243-inside-radical-entertainment-crash-of-the-titans-part-2 |accessdate=2008-05-07}} Many of the voice actors from ''Crash Tag Team Racing'' reprised their roles, including [[Jess Harnell]] as Crash Bandicoot and [[Lex Lang]] as Doctor Neo Cortex. Characters who were regulars in the series but did not appear in ''Crash Tag Team Racing'' were given new voice actors for ''Crash of the Titans''. These replacements include [[Greg Eagles]] as Aku Aku, Chris Williams as Tiny Tiger, and [[John DiMaggio]] as Uka Uka. The DS version features full voice acting for cutscenes and in-game elements by some of the same voice actors from the home console version of the game, though some of the voice actors were substituted, such as Debi Derryberry in the role of Coco Bandicoot, and [[Nolan North]] in the role of N. Gin. Dingodile, who appears only in the DS and GBA versions, is voiced by Nolan North. To make enemies memorable on their own; Radical Entertainment scripted conversations between the enemy characters that can be overheard as the player approaches. Several voice actors provide the audio for the small enemies, including [[Tom Kenny]] from [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]]'s ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]''. Adding to the game's numerous pop-culture references, the voices and mannerisms of some of the characters are based upon those of real people, including [[Mike Tyson]], [[Mr. T]], [[Jerry Lewis]], and [[Peter Lorre]].{{cite web |publisher=CAD Media |date=2007-11-07 |last=Mayo |first=Steven |title=Review - ''Crash of the Titans'' (Page 2) |url=http://www.cad-media.com/mediaitem.php?mid=552&c=psp&page=2 |accessdate=2008-06-12}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = (NDS) 73/100{{cite web |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (DS: 2007) at Metacritic |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ds/crashofthetitans?q=Crash%20of%20the%20Titans |accessdate=2007-11-04}}
(PS2) 70/100{{cite web |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (PS2: 2007) at Metacritic |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ps2/crashofthetitans?q=Crash%20of%20the%20Titans |accessdate=2007-10-24}}
(Wii) 69/100{{cite web |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (Wii: 2007) at Metacritic |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/wii/crashofthetitans?q=Crash%20of%20the%20Titans |accessdate=2007-10-01}}
(X360) 65/100{{cite web |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (X360: 2007) at Metacritic |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/xbox360/crashofthetitans?q=Crash%20of%20the%20Titans |accessdate=2007-10-24}} | EuroG = 5/10{{cite web |date=2007-10-19 |last=Reed |first=Kristan |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |title=''Crash of the Titans'' (Xbox 360: 2007) review at Eurogamer |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=85526 |accessdate=2007-10-24 |quote=If you thought that Crash's first appearance on the next generation of platforms might enhance its appeal from a technical standpoint, forget it. This is very much a game designed primarily with the PS2 and Wii in mind, with a fairly lazy high-def makeover late in development.}} | GameRev = C+{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/xbox360/playstation3/crash_of_the_titans |title=''Crash of the Titans'' video game review for the XBOX360 |accessdate=2008-10-30 |last=Rowe |first=Brian |authorlink=Brian Rowe |date=2008-01-21 |work= |publisher=[[Game Revolution]] |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=As much as I pick on Crash, I was secretly hoping that ''Crash of the Titans'' would put him back in the spotlight. It had an excitingly original concept but failed to take full advantage of its possibilities.}}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}} | GSpot = 7.0/10{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6181136 |title=''Crash of the Titans'' for Wii Review - Wii ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-10-17 |last=Davis |first=Ryan |authorlink=Ryan Davis (journalist) |date=2007-10-16 |work= |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |location= |pages= |doi= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021233603/http://www.gamespot.com/wii/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6181136 |archivedate=2007-10-21 |dead-url=yes |quote=It's a fairly sturdy, combat-heavy platformer with a good hook, but it lacks a real distinct attitude. |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox360/playstation3/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6181131 |title=''Crash of the Titans'' for Xbox 360 Review and PlayStation 3 Review - Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-12-19 |last=Davis |first=Ryan |authorlink=Ryan Davis (journalist) |date=2007-10-16 |work= |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=It's a fairly sturdy, combat-heavy platformer with a good hook, but it lacks a real distinct attitude.}}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/ps2/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6181134 |title=''Crash of the Titans'' for PlayStation 2 Review - PlayStation 2 ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-11-25 |last=Davis |first=Ryan |authorlink=Ryan Davis (journalist) |date=2007-10-16 |work= |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |location= |pages= |doi= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023070803/http://www.gamespot.com/ps2/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6181134 |archivedate=2007-10-23 |dead-url=yes |quote=It's a fairly sturdy, combat-heavy platformer with a good hook, but it lacks a real distinct attitude. |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/ds/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6182651 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130123190319/http://www.gamespot.com/ds/action/crashofthetitans/review.html?sid=6182651 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-23 |title=''Crash of the Titans'' for Nintendo DS Review - Nintendo DS ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2008-02-05 |last=Provo |first=Frank |date=2007-11-09 |work= |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=There's plenty to do, and controlling the enemy is a neat twist, but the adventure is over too soon.}} | GameZone = (NDS) 6.9/10{{cite web|url=http://nds.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r32363.htm |title=''CRASH of the Titans'' Review - Nintendo DS |accessdate=2008-10-15 |last=Bedigian |first=Louis |date=2007-11-01 |work= |publisher=GameZone |location= |pages= |doi= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705142841/http://nds.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r32363.htm |archivedate=July 5, 2008 |quote=Close to achieving Naughty Dog greatness in level design but far away from that success in other areas, ''Crash of the Titans'' isn't on par with its 2D, Game Boy Advance predecessors. |deadurl=yes }}
(Wii) 6.8/10{{cite web|url=http://wii.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r32363.htm |title=''CRASH of the Titans'' Review - Wii |accessdate=2008-10-15 |last=Knutson |first=Michael |date=2007-10-30 |work= |publisher=GameZone |location= |pages= |doi= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006030336/http://wii.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r32363.htm |archivedate=2008-10-06 |quote=This is a decent game that could have used a bit more innovation to really make this game top notch and stand out from all of the other platform games already available on this system. |deadurl=yes |df= }}
(X360) and (PS3) 6.4/10{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r32363.htm |title=''CRASH of the Titans'' Review - Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 |accessdate=2008-10-15 |last=Grabowski |first=Dakota |date=2007-11-01 |work= |publisher=GameZone |location= |pages= |doi= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006035655/http://xbox360.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r32363.htm |archivedate=2008-10-06 |quote=Save for the cooperative mode, theres not much here worthy of a gamers time that is devoted to buying and renting the best games. |deadurl=yes |df= }} | IGN = (NDS) 8.0/10{{cite web |url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/826/826456p1.html |title=IGN: ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-10-23 |last=Harris |first=Craig (journalist) |date=2007-10-10 |work= |publisher=IGN |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=Definitely one of the better handheld Crash games to hit the market.}}
6.5/10{{cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/827/827903p1.html |title=IGN: ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-10-17 |last=Periera |first=Michael |date=2007-10-16 |work= |publisher=IGN |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=A good idea wrapped in a mediocre game.}}{{cite web |url=http://xbox360.ign.com/articles/827/827884p1.html |title=IGN: ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-10-17 |last=Periera |first=Michael |date=2007-10-16 |work= |publisher=IGN |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=A good idea wrapped in a mediocre game.}}{{cite web |url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/827/827898p1.html |title=IGN: ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-10-17 |last=Periera |first=Michael |date=2007-10-16 |work= |publisher=IGN |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=A good idea wrapped in a mediocre game.}}
(PSP) 6.3/10{{cite web |url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/826/826456p1.html |title=IGN: ''Crash of the Titans'' Review |accessdate=2007-10-28 |last=Periera |first=Michael |date=2007-10-26 |work= |publisher=IGN |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=''Crash of the Titans'' for PSP is a decent port of a briefly entertaining game. But even then, the PSP version loses out to the consoles in a number of areas; especially when it comes to multiplayer.}} | NWR = 7.5/10{{cite web |last=Miller |first=Zachary |date=2007-10-26 |publisher=[[Nintendo World Report]]| title=''Crash of the Titans'' (DS: 2007) at Nintendo World Report |url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/reviewArt.cfm?artid=14681 |accessdate=2007-10-28 |quote=A mediocre game with some interesting ideas. ''Crash Bandicoot'' fans should enjoy it, but gamers looking for a decent platformer on their DS should look elsewhere.}} | VG = 7/10{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/wii/crash_of_the_titans/review.html |title=''Crash of the Titans'' Review for Wii - VideoGamer.com |accessdate=2008-10-30 |author= |last=Freeman |first=Will |date=2007-11-22 |work= |publisher=VideoGamer.com |location= |pages= |doi= |quote=Still, it is a pleasure to find that while lacking in any real finesse, ''Titans'' does feel like a proper ''Crash Bandicoot'' title. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906001859/http://www.videogamer.com/wii/crash_of_the_titans/review.html |archivedate=2008-09-06 |df= }} }} ''Crash of the Titans'' received mixed to average reviews upon its release, except for the DS version, which received positive reviews. [[GameSpot]] credited it as a "fairly sturdy, combat-heavy platformer with a good hook", but concluded that it lacked the distinctive style of past ''Crash Bandicoot'' games. The DS version of the game was reviewed positively, with [[IGN]] naming it "one of the better handheld Crash games to hit the market". Nintendo World Report gave the DS version a higher score than the home console version by half a point, but dismissed it as "a short game that has very little gameplay variety". GameSpot proclaimed that "there's plenty to do, and controlling the enemy is a neat twist", but criticized the game's small length of only six to eight hours. The more negative reviews include those from ''[[Nintendo Power]]'', who criticized the game for its "fixed and unforgiving" camera, which they felt made the platforming experience "frustrating". [[GameSpy]] also criticized the game for its camera along with its unsteady framerate, but praised the game's attractive graphics and offline co-op mode. IGN described the game as "a good idea wrapped in a mediocre game", dismissing the game's music as "forgettable", and hoping that the jacking concept would be refined for a possible sequel. [[Eurogamer]] was also critical of ''Crash of the Titans'', deriding its graphics as "designed primarily with the PS2 and Wii in mind, with a fairly lazy high-def makeover late in development". The PSP version received less praise than its console counterparts, with IGN remarking that it "loses out to the consoles in a number of areas; especially when it comes to multiplayer". ''Crash of the Titans'' was a nominee in the [[Writers Guild of America]]'s inaugural video game writing awards, competing against ''[[Dead Head Fred]]'', ''[[The Simpsons Game]]'', ''[[The Witcher (video game)|The Witcher]]'' and ''[[World in Conflict]]'';{{cite web |publisher=Variety's Award Central |date=2008-01-14 |last=McNary |first=Dave |title=WGA announces videogame nominees |url=http://www.variety.com/awardcentral_article/VR1117979031.html?nav=news&categoryid=1983&cs=1 |accessdate=2008-01-17}} ''Dead Head Fred'' won the award.{{cite web|last=Androvich |first=Mark |date=2008-02-15 |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=33202 |title=''Dead Head Fred'' wins inaugural WGA award |publisher=gamesindustry.biz |accessdate=2008-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218110816/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=33202 |archivedate=February 18, 2008 }}{{cite web |last=Grant |first=Christopher |date=2008-02-15 |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2008/02/15/dead-head-fred-wins-wgas-first-video-game-writing-award/ |title=''Dead Head Fred'' wins WGA's first Video Game Writing Award |publisher=joystiq.com |accessdate=2008-02-15}} ''Crash of the Titans'' was also selected as a nominee in the "Best Sound Design" and "Best Character" categories of the Second Annual Elan Awards.{{cite web|publisher=Radical Entertainment |title=Radical Entertainment News & Updates |url=http://www.radical.ca/news.cfm |accessdate=2008-03-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206234010/http://www.radical.ca/news.cfm |archivedate=2008-02-06 |deadurl=yes |df= }} It lost both awards to ''[[Skate (video game)|Skate]]'' and ''[[Mass Effect]]'''s [[Characters of Mass Effect#Commander Shepard|Commander Shepard]] respectively.{{cite web|publisher=The Elans |title=The 2nd Annual Elans Canadian Awards for the Electronic and the Animated Arts winners |url=http://theelans.com/Winners.html |accessdate=2008-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312093236/http://theelans.com/Winners.html |archivedate=March 12, 2008 }} In Australia, ''Crash of the Titans'' was the second highest-selling game in its first week below ''[[Halo 3]]''.{{cite web |date=2007-11-01 |publisher=Kotaku |last=Pluckett |first=Luke |title=Aussie Sales Charts |url=http://kotaku.com/gaming/sales-charts/aussie-sales-charts-317589.php |accessdate=2008-05-10}} The game was not as successful in the United Kingdom, where the PS2 version of the game debuted at #32 in the sales charts.{{cite web |date=2007-10-16 |publisher=Gamasutra |title=''Project Gotham Racing 4'' Wins Kudos In UK Sales Chart |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=15869 |accessdate=2008-05-10 |quote=The charts do feature some genuine new entries, with the PlayStation 3 version of Electronic Arts' ''Skate'' debuting at number twenty-five and the PlayStation 2 version of Vivendi's ''Crash of the Titans'' at number thirty-two.}} The game made [[pound sterling|£]]3.35 million in the UK, by the end of 2007.{{cite web |date=2008-04-10 |publisher=develop |title=Develop 100: #31 - #50 Profiles |url=http://www.developmag.com/interviews/161/Develop-100-31-50-Profiles |accessdate=2008-05-10}} Despite the poor sales in the UK, the game was re-released on [[Essentials (PlayStation)|Platinum]] for the PlayStation and for the [[Platinum Hits|Xbox 360 Classics]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130531050749/http://village.crashbandicoot.com/splash/ Official website] {{Crash Bandicoot series}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crash Of The Titans}} [[Category:2007 video games]] [[Category:3D platform games]] [[Category:Cooperative video games]] games]]

revision.comment: [[WP:CHECKWIKI|Checkwiki]] error fix #17. Unnecessary duplicate categories found using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = | image = Crusader- A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem.jpg | caption = Cover art | developer = [[Index+]] | publisher = [[Europress]] | composer = Olivier Pryszlak | producer = Édouard Lussan | engine = | released = 1997 (Original)
2000 (Rearranged) | genre = Historical adventure | modes = [[Single-player]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]
[[Windows 3.x]]
[[Mac OS X]] }} '''''Crusader: Adventure Out of Time''''', also known as ''Crusader: A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem'' is a 1997 video game, developed by [[Index+]] and published by [[Europress]]. The game was published for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Windows 3.x]] and [[Mac OS X]]. == Gameplay == The game features 26 levels and is set in 1183, in the Kingdom of Jerusalem, at which time the relics of the Holy Cross are in danger. Videos of 20 actors are integrated into the computer graphics during gameplay. == Development == A rearranged version of the game was released in 1999, as ''Crusaders 2000'', featuring new puzzles. The game was not published in Russia.{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=http://questzone.ru/enzi/game/4094&prev=search|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.com.au|access-date=2018-02-23}} == Critical reception == Just Adventure thought the game was like playing a fun history report,{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021225160416/http://www.justadventure.com:80/reviews/Crusader/Crusader2.shtm|title=Review: Crusader: A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem|date=2002-12-25|access-date=2018-02-23}} while a different review by the same website found it to be both magnetic and generally enjoyable.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021022224148/http://www.justadventure.com:80/reviews/Crusader/Crusader.shtm|title=Review: Crusader: A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem|date=2002-10-22|access-date=2018-02-23}} Electric Playground thought the game was identical to [[Vikings (video game)|Vikings]] sans the historical setting, though noted that Crusader had a more complex story and gameplay.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529123301/http://www.tap-repeatedly.com/Reviews/Crusader/Crusader.shtml|title=Four Fat Chicks -- Crusader: A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem|date=2016-05-29|access-date=2018-02-23}} On the contrary, Quandaryland thought that Crusader seemed flatter, and less life-like than Vikings.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406201126/http://www.quandaryland.com:80/jsp/dispArticle.jsp?index=438|title=Crusader: A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem Review by Quandary|date=2004-04-06|access-date=2018-02-23}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.metzomagic.com/showArticle.php?index=438|title=Crusader: A Conspiracy in the Kingdom of Jerusalem Review by metzomagic.com|website=www.metzomagic.com|access-date=2018-02-23}} While Nquest positively reviewed the title, it argued that it was more of an interactive encyclopedia than a game.{{Cite web|url=https://translate.google.com.au/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=http://nquest.ucoz.com/index/0-337&prev=search|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.com.au|access-date=2018-02-23}} Realising Multimedia Potential deemed the game a "new way to approach history".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=kfzaAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Crusader:+Adventure+Out+of+Time%22+OR+%22Cruzadas:+Conspiraci%C3%B3n+en+el+Reino+de+Oriente%22+OR+%22Cruzadas:+Conspiraci%C3%B3n+en+el+Reino+de+Jerusalen%22+OR+%22Crusader:+Kreuzz%C3%BCge+-+Verschw%C3%B6rung+im+K%C3%B6nigreich+des+Orients%22+OR+%22Crusader:+A+Conspiracy+in+the+Kingdom+of+Jerusalem%22+OR+%22Croisades.+Conspiration+au+Royaume+d'Orient+%22&dq=%22Crusader:+Adventure+Out+of+Time%22+OR+%22Cruzadas:+Conspiraci%C3%B3n+en+el+Reino+de+Oriente%22+OR+%22Cruzadas:+Conspiraci%C3%B3n+en+el+Reino+de+Jerusalen%22+OR+%22Crusader:+Kreuzz%C3%BCge+-+Verschw%C3%B6rung+im+K%C3%B6nigreich+des+Orients%22+OR+%22Crusader:+A+Conspiracy+in+the+Kingdom+of+Jerusalem%22+OR+%22Croisades.+Conspiration+au+Royaume+d'Orient+%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-vaehzrvZAhXLvLwKHdKzDTEQ6AEIKTAA|title=Realising Multimedia Potential:: Development Projects Supported by the Info2000 Programme|last=Querée|first=Anne|date=1997|publisher=Office for Official Publications of the European Communities|isbn=9789282826065|language=en}} Jeuxvideo felt that Crusaders 2000 was effectively an unnecessary copy of the original.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430135433/http://www.jeuxvideo.com:80/articles/0000/00000018_test.htm|title=Test du jeu Croisades 2000 sur PC - jeuxvideo.com|date=2016-04-30|access-date=2018-02-23}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/crusader-adventure-out-of-time}} [[Category:Video games developed in France]] set in Jerusalem]] {{adventure-videogame-stub}}

[[File:Cullen Garden and Miniature village.jpg|thumb|300px|Cullen Garden and Miniature village in Whitby]] [[File:Cullen Garden and Miniature Village, Whitby,ON.jpg|thumb|300px|Cullen Garden and Miniature Village, Whitby, ON]] [[File:Miniature Village Cullen Garden.jpg|thumb|300px|Miniature Village, Cullen Garden, Whitby, ON]] '''Cullen Gardens & Miniature Village''' was a popular tourist attraction in [[Whitby, Ontario]], Canada. Officially opened in May 1980 by founder Len Cullen and his wife, Connie, the Gardens were a major tourist attraction in [[Whitby]] for 25 years.<ref>[http://www.markcullen.com/news_events/cullen_gardens.htm MarkCullen.com: Cullen Gardens ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070122012941/http://www.markcullen.com/news_events/cullen_gardens.htm |date=January 22, 2007 }}</ref>
== Features and attractions ==
Cullen Gardens combined the natural beauty of floral displays and gardens, along with a unique southern Ontario-themed miniature village. The miniature village included many houses and [[Ridable miniature railway|trains]] that would travel around and between the houses. Other features included radio-controlled miniature boats. It was an entertaining attraction for both children and adults. In 1983, the Miniature Village served as the filming location for an episode of the Canadian television series ''[[The Littlest Hobo]]'', entitled "Small Pleasures" (season 4, episode 16).
=== Festival of Lights ===
During the Winter holiday season, Cullen Gardens was host to the Festival of Lights, which featured huge displays of Christmas lights throughout the grounds, often decorating large topiaries.
== Closure and redevelopment==
On 1 January 2006, Cullen Gardens and Miniature Village closed. The land, however, has since been purchased by the Town of Whitby, to remain in the public domain as a [[municipal park]]. There has been speculation that the property may link up with the Heber Downs [[conservation area]]. At the time of its closure, the park was co-owned by Sue Cullen-Green and Bryan Green.
The miniature Village no longer exists at the site and the model buildings were sold to the nearby City of [[Oshawa]] for $234,000. Oshawa later put them up for sale again rather than opening an attraction of its own, citing budgetary austerity.<ref>"Oshawa will sell miniature village" October 17, 2007. [https://www.thestar.com/News/article/267665 TheStar.com - Toronto Edition], Retrieved July 15, 2008.</ref> The golf course formerly attached to Cullen Gardens continues to operate.
The miniature buildings were purchased by the [[Niagara Parks Commission]] in 2012. Many of the miniature buildings are now on display at the NPC's Botanical Gardens in Niagara Falls, Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.niagarafrontier.com/greenhouse.html |title=Niagara Parks Commission Floral Showhouse |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=May 3, 2014 |website=Niagarafrontier.com |publisher= |accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref>
In November 2011, the Town entered into a purchase and sale agreement with Auberge et Spa Le Nordik Inc. of [[Chelsea, Quebec]]. Le Nordik bought the main building and 3 hectares of land. They intend to use the main building and outdoor area to build a year-round heat therapy spa with two restaurants, a retail boutique and a small conference area. The remaining land was designated as open space and parkland, known as '''Cullen Central Park'''. The deal closed in 2013 and the spa was supposed to open in 2015.<ref>"Cullen revival imminent with Whitby spa development" June 27, 2013. As of September 2014, a park dedicated to fallen Canadian soldiers is now being constructed in Cullen Gardens. It was supposed to be done by November 2014. [http://www.durhamregion.com/news-story/3858357-cullen-revival-imminent-with-whitby-spa-development/ Whitby This Week], Retrieved August 15, 2013.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

Retrieved July 15, 2008

{{multiple issues| {{globalize/US|date=May 2010}} {{update|date=May 2010}} }}
[[Image:Converterbox.JPG|thumb|right|A digital TV converter box]] A '''digital television adapter''' ('''DTA'''), commonly known as a '''converter box''', is a [[tuner (television)|television tuner]] that receives a [[digital television]] (DTV) transmission, and converts the [[Digital signal (broadcasting)|digital signal]] into an [[analog signal]] that can be received and displayed on an [[analog television]] set. The input digital signal may be over-the-air [[terrestrial television]] signals received by a [[television antenna]], or signals from a [[digital cable]] system. It normally does not refer to [[satellite TV]], which has always required a [[set-top box]] either to operate the [[TVRO|big]] [[satellite dish]], or to be the [[integrated receiver/decoder]] (IRD) in the case of [[direct-broadcast satellite]]s (DBS).
In [[North America]], these [[ATSC tuner]] boxes convert from [[ATSC]] to [[NTSC]], while in most of [[Europe]] and other places such as [[Australia]], they convert from [[Digital Video Broadcasting]] (DVB) to [[PAL]]. Because the [[DTV transition]] did nothing to reduce the number of [[broadcast television system]] standards (and in fact further complicated them), and due to varying [[frequency allocation]]s and [[bandplan]]s, there are many other combinations specific to other countries.
==United States== On June 12, 2009, all full-power [[analog television]] transmissions ended in the United States. Viewers who watch [[broadcast television]] on older analog TV sets must use a DTA. Since many of the [[low-power TV]] stations will continue to broadcast in analog for years to come, consumers who watch low-power stations will need an adapter with an [[analog passthrough]] feature that allows the viewer to watch both digital and analog signals. Viewers who receive their television signals through cable or satellite were not affected by this change and did not need a digital television adapter (however, see the cable TV exception below). Additionally, viewers who have newer televisions with built-in digital ATSC tuners will not need an external digital television adapter.
The United States government had set up a program to offer consumers a $40 "coupon" which could be used toward the purchase of a [[coupon-eligible converter box]]; that program ended in July 2006.
===History=== At the [[Consumer Electronics Association]]'s Entertainment Technology Policy Summit in January 2006, [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) [[Commissioner]] [[Jonathan Adelstein]] said many Americans did not know about the February 17, 2006, deadline for ending analog TV. Furthermore, he said, too many people were still buying analog TV sets, meaning more demand for converter boxes. And even if people found out what they would have to do, converter boxes might not do the job adequately. [[Tribune Broadcasting]] chief technology officer Ira Goldstone said just buying a converter box did not necessarily mean getting the latest technology. Bob Seidel of [[CBS]] said companies (especially in countries other than the US) might use cheaper tuners, and people would need new television antennas for proper reception. [[Circuit City (1949–2009 company)|Circuit City]] Chairman Alan McCollough opposed converter boxes, saying people should just buy digital TVs, and [[television network]]s should offer only [[widescreen]]-format [[television program]]ming as an incentive to do that.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/99747-High_Hurdles_in_Digital_TV_Race.php |title=High Hurdles in Digital-TV Race |work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |first=Glen |last=Dickson |date=2006-03-19 |accessdate=2009-08-12}}</ref>
[[Prototype]]s of the first converter boxes appeared at the [[National Association of Broadcasters|NAB]] show in 2006. [[LG Electronics]], which took over [[Zenith Electronics]] in 1999, showed its model connected to a Zenith TV from 1980, while [[Thomson SA|Thomson Consumer Electronics]] used an [[RCA]] TV from 1987 for its demonstration. Both boxes shown used [[electronic program guide]]s using [[Program and System Information Protocol]] (PSIP). The devices showed program details, [[V-chip]] ratings and signal strength. Thomson's model stored three days of TV listings, allowed parental controls, and could set a [[VCR]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/103959-Old_TVs_Steal_Show_at_NAB.php |title=Old TVs Steal Show at NAB |work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |first=Glen |last=Dickson |date=2006-04-30 |accessdate=2009-08-12}}</ref>
===Differences for cable customers=== Cable TV systems are under no deadline to convert to digital TV. However, many [[Comcast]] (and some other cable TV) customers are finding all of their non-local and non-[[Shopping channel|shopping networks]] eliminated on various dates, even though only a few are needed for additional [[digital cable]] channels. CECBs (Coupon-eligible converter boxes) will not work on these systems because cable ATSC uses [[Quadrature amplitude modulation|256QAM]] [[modulation]] instead of [[8VSB]], and so a separate but similar DTA with a [[QAM (television)|QAM tuner]] is necessary. If the cable company takes away analog channels, at least two of these adapters must be provided for free by the cable company for at least three years so that customers can continue to watch the same channels with existing equipment.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} Cable companies were required to provide some analog service until October 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/business/technology/article11054294.html|title=Time Warner Cable changes mean every TV needs a box now|last=Davis|first=Mark|work=[[Kansas City Star]]|date=2015-02-24|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> After that, taking away analog channels allowed faster Internet and more [[High-definition television|HD channels]]. An adapter from the cable provider was needed even for digital TVs if the company [[Television encryption|scrambled]] its digital signals to prevent [[Copyright infringement#.22Piracy.22|piracy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-laz-time-warner-cable-box-20141024-story.html|title=Can you go to Best Buy for Time Warner Cable's new box?|last=Lazarus|first=David|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2014-10-24|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>
A digital transport adapter will allow viewing of basic channels, often as many as 99, but not [[Pay television|premium channels]]. It will also not allow [[video on demand]] or [[pay-per-view]]. Simple DTAs only allow analog sets to receive digital signals using [[Radio frequency|RF]] output on channel 3 or 4, using [[coaxial cable]]. Other versions of the DTA are available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dslreports.com/faq/16218|title=What is a DTA? What channels can I get with a DTA? What about those new HD-DTA?|publisher=dslreports.com|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>
[[Pace plc]] developed the XiD-P digital transport adapter for [[Comcast]], allowing [[Ultra-high-definition television|4K]] service and offering the potential to expand the DTA from one-way to two-way. This would involve adding [[Internet Protocol|IP]] capability.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Device Could Speed Comcast's IP-Video Migration|last=Baumgartner|first=Jeff|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=2015-06-01|page=9}}</ref>
==European Union== Most countries that have switched to digital TV use [[DVB-T]] broadcasting with [[MPEG-2]] [[MPEG-2#Video profiles and levels|MP@ML]] or H.264 encoding. Some, however, consider switching to [[DVB-T2]] such as the [[United Kingdom|UK]], being the first to test DVB-T2. This results in a number of different combinations for external digital receivers with the MPEG-2 ones sold at about €15 to €35 and the MPEG-4 ones reaching €25 to €150. Currently, all set top boxes sold in EU cannot exceed 0.5W in stand by mode.
== See also == * [[Cable converter box]] * [[Digital television transition]] * [[DTV transition in the United States]] * [[Set-top box]]
== References ==
{{Reflist}} * ''Request for Comment and Notice of Proposed Rules to Implement and Administer a Coupon Program for Digital-to-Analog Converter Boxes'', Docket Number 060512129-6129-01 (Jul. 25, 2006).

{{refimprove|date=January 2015}} '''Eagle Games''', now known as Eagle-Gryphon games, is a [[board game]] publisher.
==Background== Eagle Games was founded in 2001 by Glenn Drover, and was bought by [[Ashland, Oregon]]-based FRED Distribution, Inc. doing business as Gryphon Games in 2007. From 2007 to 2014 they published games under the two lines as Gryphon Games and Eagle Games.
They are currently based in [[Leitchfield, Kentucky]] and are now known as Eagle-Gryphon Games. Eagle-Gryphon Games is known for a large catalog of games that range from fast, fun family games to larger strategy games with longer game time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eaglegames.net/AboutUs.asp|title=About Us|website=Eagle Games|accessdate=January 28, 2015}}</ref>
==Board games==
Notable titles *''[[Through the Ages]]'' *''Age of Steam'' *''[[Brass (board game)|Brass]]'' *''[[Conquest of the Empire]]'' *''Francis Drake'' *''Defenders of the Realm'' *''Triassic Terror'' *''Rococo'' *''The Railways of the World series'' *''Baseball Highlights 2045'' *''Roll Through the Ages: Bronze Age'' *''Roll Through the Ages: Iron Age'' *''For Sale'' *''[[Incan Gold]]'' *''Fantastiqa'' *''Fleet'' *''[[I'm the Boss]]'' *''Master's Gallery'' *''Cheeky Monkey'' *''[[Take It Easy (game)|Take It Easy]]'' *''The Pick A Pig/Pick A Dog/Pick A Polar Bear series'' *''Pastiche''

The '''Evil Overlord List''', also known as '''If I Were An Evil Overlord''', is one of several popular lists of planned actions for a competent [[Dark Lord|Evil Overlord]] to avoid the well-known, [[cliché]] blunders committed by [[supervillains]] in popular fictional works, typically explained in a [[comedy|comical]] fashion. The lists were compiled by [[science fiction]] fans over a number of years, and copies of the list that can be found on the Internet vary in number and order of entries.
==History== The most famous specific lists, both referred to as the '''Evil Overlord List''', were developed concurrently. Both were published to the web in the early 1990s. The original, if lesser-known list was compiled in 1990 by members of the now-defunct [[FidoNet]] Science Fiction and Fandom (SFFAN) email echo. The FidoNet list originated with a 1988 ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' skit featuring [[James Bond|Bond]] Villains touting a book "What Not To Do When You Capture James Bond". The FidoNet list arose out of discussions regarding what sort of advice might be in that book, and was compiled and published by Jack Butler. It predated the following list, but was only widely published later, and is the more obscure of the two.
The later-produced and more famous version of the list was compiled in 1994 by Peter Anspach (hence it is occasionally titled "Peter's Evil Overlord List") based on informal discussions at conventions and on online bulletin boards in the early 1990s,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eviloverlord.com/lists/overlord.html |title=Peter's Evil Overlord List |last=Anspach |first=Peter |accessdate=September 26, 2006}}</ref> and has subsequently become one of the best-known parodies of bad [[Speculative fiction|SF/F]] writing, frequently referenced online. It was originally '''The Top 100 Things I'd Do If I Ever Became An Evil Overlord''', but grew to include over 100 entries.
Anspach and Butler acknowledge the existence of each other's lists, and state that their two lists have been so cross-pollinated over the years as to become effectively identical.
The Evil Overlord List has led to spinoffs, including lists for [[stock character]]s including (but not limited to) [[hero]]es, [[Henchman|henchmen]], [[sidekick]]s, the Evil Overlord's [[Accountant]], and [[Starfleet]] captains.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.sff.net/paradise/overlord.html |title=Stupid Plot Tricks - The Evil Overlord Devises a Plot |accessdate=2006-12-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930165417/http://www.sff.net/paradise/overlord.html |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref>
==Usage== In [[Australia]], a minor literary scandal erupted in 1997 when it emerged that award-winning author [[Helen Darville]] [[plagiarism|plagiarised]] this list for her regular column in [[Brisbane]]'s ''[[The Courier-Mail|Courier-Mail]]'' newspaper, which led to her being fired.<ref>{{cite journal|first=David|last=Greason|title=The Review – TZADIK|publisher=Australia/Israel & Jewish Affairs Council|journal=|url=http://www.aijac.org.au/review/1997/222/tzad222.html|accessdate=26 September 2006|date=15 February 1997|volume=|number=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061012013532/http://www.aijac.org.au/review/1997/222/tzad222.html|archivedate=12 October 2006|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[The Australian]]|title=Editor dumps Darville|page=3|date=5 February 1997|url=|accessdate=|author=}}</ref>
[[Teresa Nielsen Hayden]], noted author and lecturer, uses an expanded version of the list in her lectures on writing science fiction. She recommends selecting five [[random plot generator|random]] clichés from the list, and using them, or their reverse ("Say you've drawn A-34, 'I will not turn into a snake. It never helps.' You can have a character turn into a snake and find it doesn't help, or do it and find it very useful indeed") as the basis for a plot.<ref name=Hayden>[http://www.sff.net/paradise/plottricks.htm "The Evil Overlord Devises a Plot"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930165557/http://www.sff.net/paradise/plottricks.htm |date=2007-09-30 }} Excerpted from Teresa Nielsen Hayden lecture on Stupid Plotting Tricks</ref>
From 2001–2002, the alt.eo [[Alt.* hierarchy]] [[newsgroup]] was dedicated to discussing and adding to the list.<ref name=alteo>[http://www.faqs.org/faqs/humor/evil-overlords/ "Official Alt.eo FAQ v0.1.2"], 8 December 2002</ref>
In 2007, issue #6 of [[Marvel Comics]]' ''[[Heroes for Hire]]'' featured a [[Doctor Doom|Doombot]] which had been reprogrammed with the contents of the list.
''If I Were An Evil Overlord'', a 2007 short story anthology edited by [[Martin H. Greenberg]] and Russell Davis, explicitly references the various lists as source material.
[[PS238]], issue 33 (published in 2008), includes a mention of the EOL in the main story, plus an appendix with fifty major points from the list. <ref> Aaron Williams, ''PS238'', issue 33, July 2008. </ref>
In the [[S.M. Stirling]] novel ''The Protector's War'', excerpts from the list are printed in the back of the book of plans distributed to the Protector's subordinate nobles.
[[Jim Butcher]] refers to the list a number of times in his contemporary fantasy series, [[The Dresden Files]].
In May 2012, students from [[Lehigh University]] of Pennsylvania published a blog post that examined how much it would cost to follow all of the instructions on the list. The students concluded that while some money would be saved, overall it would require $14,268,632.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.centives.net/S/2012/the-cost-of-being-an-unbeatable-evil-overlord-2/| title=The Cost Of Being An Unbeatable Evil Overlord| publisher=Centives| date=May 27, 2012| accessdate=2012-05-27}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
== External links ==
* [http://legendspbem.angelfire.com/eviloverlordlist.html The Original Evil Overlord List] (Jack Butler's FidoNet list) * [http://www.eviloverlord.com Peter Anspach's Version Of The Evil Overlord List], at eviloverlord.com (Started subsequent to the Butler list, and created during an overlapping time period, with an independent origin. Copyrighted by Mr. Anspach, and partially but not entirely created by him.) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nH3JF_5cCok Evil Overlord] A short film based on the list above created by members of the [[Imperial College]] Science Fiction Society. * [http://nielsenhayden.com/overlord/ Random Plot Generator] random selections from the list, hosted by [[Teresa Nielsen Hayden]] * {{tvtropes|JustForFun/TVTropesAdditionalEvilOverlordVows|Just For Fun / TV Tropes Additional Evil Overlord Vows }}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{distinguish|Free-to-air}} '''Free-to-view''' ('''FTV''') is a term used for audio and/or video transmissions that are provided free-of-charge without any form of continual subscription but are nevertheless [[encryption|encrypted]].<ref>"A-Z Of Satellite TV: F" ''What Satellite & Digital TV'' October 2012 pp37</ref> It differs from [[free-to-air]] (FTA) where content is not encrypted.
==Free-to-view vs. Free-to-air== The free-to-view system contrasts with [[free-to-air]] (FTA), in which signals are transmitted in the clear, without [[encryption]], and can be received by anyone with a suitable receiving [[satellite dish|dish]] antenna and [[Digital Video Broadcasting|DVB]]-compliant receiver (although these services can include proprietary encrypted data services such as an [[electronic program guide|EPG]] that is only available to reception equipment made for, or authorised by, the FTA broadcaster). Free-to-view services are broadcast encrypted and can only be viewed with reception equipment that includes a suitable [[conditional-access module]] and viewing card, in the same way as a [[pay-TV]] satellite service. However, the FTV service viewing card is not subject to a continuing subscription payment for viewing the service's channels and may be available for a regular fee, a one-off payment or even for free.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}}
Services which charge a regular fee for reception can still be considered free-to-view, and not [[pay-TV]] if the fee is not for the programming content but for the delivery. {{Disputed inline|date=January 2015}} For example, the HD+ service in Germany, which broadcasts [[High-definition television|HD]] versions of channels which are also available free-to-air in standard definition, defended its service fee saying it "is related to the reception of the offer and not to specific content, parts or packages of the offer".<ref>Briel, Robert [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2009/09/10/kayser-give-details-about-hd-platform/''Kayser rebuffs critics of HD+ platform''] ''Broadband TV News'' 10 September 2009. Accessed 30 November 2014</ref>
==Commercial restrictions and targeting== The free-to-view system allows for restricting access based on location of the viewer. For example, in the UK prior to the launch of [[Astra 2D]], UK channels broadcasting from the [[Astra 28.2°E]] satellites used a wide beam and could be received across Europe on small dishes. Those channels which were non-subscription but aimed at the UK only, or restricted from broadcasting outside the UK by way of programme rights (such as [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]) or governance (such as the [[BBC]] channels), were broadcast encrypted using [[Videoguard]] (as used by [[Sky (United Kingdom)|Sky (UK)]] for its pay-TV services) with viewing cards made available to UK residents only.<ref>Bains, Geoff. "Flight of the Big Birds" ''What Satellite & Digital TV'' February 2012 pp29</ref>
The launch of Astra 2D with a broadcast beam narrowly aimed at the UK and Ireland only enabled UK channels to switch from broadcasting free-to-view to free-to-air, while maintaining their UK exclusivity. The decline of UK free-to-view in favour of narrow-beamed free-to-air has been gradual:
*The BBC's eight digital channels were encrypted under the scheme from their launch on digital satellite until 14 July 2003, when they became free-to-air. *Shortly after this, ITV stated its intentions to go free-to-air eventually, and launched their newest channel, [[ITV3]], in the clear on 1 November 2004. *This was followed up by ITV moving its [[Men & Motors]] channel to FTA in July 2005. *This gradual conversion was completed on 1 November 2005, with [[ITV1]] and [[ITV2]] going FTA. ITV's latest channel, [[ITV4]], was launched at the same time, also as a free-to-air service. All the BBC and ITV channels at this time could be viewed FTA without any subscription or purchase from Sky. *However, in June 2008, some ITV regional channels were encrypted again due to one of their narrow beam transponder agreements ending. *In April, 2011, high definition [[Channel 4 HD]] moved from being a free-to-view channel to a free-to-air channel (when moving to a transponder on Eurobird). *1 December 2011, [[5USA]], 5USA+1, [[5*]] and 5*+1 became free-to-air after moving to [[Astra 1N]]. *6 June 2012, [[Pick TV]] and Pick TV +1 became free-to-air. *During October 2012, the final free-to-view regions of [[ITV1]], ITV1 +1 and [[ITV1 HD]] became free-to-air. *25 March 2013, [[Viva (UK & Ireland)|Viva]] went free-to-air. *28 October 2013, Channel 5 HD switched from free-to-view became a subscription channel on the Sky digital satellite platform and is no longer a channel. *[[LFC TV]] switched from free-to-view to Sky subscription only. *7 February 2017, [[4Music]] became free-to-air.
The remaining channel aimed exclusively at the UK that use the [[Astra (satellite)|Astra]] satellites at 28.2°E with a Europe-wide beam and remain free-to-view and encrypted is [[Sony Entertainment Television (UK & Ireland)|Sony Entertainment Television]] and they can be viewed with a Sky Videoguard receiver and a Sky viewing card, either an inactive former Sky pay-TV card or one for the [[Freesat from Sky]] package, bought for a one-off fee.<ref>[http://www.sky.com/shop/freesat/home/what-can-i-watch/ List of Freesat from Sky channels] Accessed 30 November 2014</ref>
==Free-to-view Networks== {{unreferenced section|date=December 2014}} *[[Freesat]] from Sky A UK satellite service from Sky (UK) offering 240 free-to-air and free-to-view TV channels and the Sky EPG, with a one-off payment for a Sky receiver, dish, installation and viewing card.
*[[HD+]]{{disputed inline|date=January 2015}} A package of 21 high definition digital satellite TV channels for German-speaking viewers and a subsidiary company of satellite owner [[SES S.A.|SES]], with a monthly or annual fee for the viewing card.
*[[Viewer Access Satellite Television]] Australian satellite television platform providing digital TV and radio services to remote and rural areas, and terrestrial black spots. VAST is partly funded by the Australian Government and requires a certified set-top box and viewing card.
*Fransat A package of mostly HD channels broadcast to residents of France who cannot receive the digital terrestrial TV channels. Can be received all over Europe on Eutelsat 5WA, historical position for French free TV. Viewing card does not expire.
*[[Tivù Sat]] Italian package of 68 free-to-air and free-to-view satellite channels for viewers unable to receive them on national terrestrial TV networks. Requires a [[Nagravision]] receiver and viewing card.
*TNTSAT Same as Fransat, TNTSAT broadcasts the all-HD channels from French free digital terrestrial television. TNTSAT is issued by Canal + group on its main position, Astra 1. Viewing card has to be renewed every 4 years. TNTSAT compatible equipment is also compatible with CANALSAT pay TV.
*[[Tricolor TV]] Russian satellite TV service partly operating within the free-to-view model.
==See also== *[[Free TV Alliance]] - European organisation promoting free-to-air and free-to-view TV *[[Freesat]] - UK free-to-air network *Fransat - France free-to-view TV
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.manhattan-tv.com] *[http://www.manhattan-tv.com/products/plaza-hd-t2-freeview-hd] *[http://www.manhattan-tv.com/products/plaza-hd-t2-freeview-hd]
{{Broadcast encryption}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Free-To-View}} [[Category:Television terminology]]
