{{Culture of Bulgaria}} The '''media of Bulgaria''' refers to [[mass media]] outlets based in [[Bulgaria]]. Television, magazines, and newspapers are all operated by both state-owned and for-profit corporations which depend on [[advertising]], [[subscription]], and other sales-related revenues. The [[Constitution of Bulgaria]] guarantees freedom of speech. As a [[country in transition]], Bulgaria's media system is under transformation.
Bulgaria's media are generally deemed unbiased, although the state still dominates the field through the [[Bulgarian National Television]] (BNT), the [[Bulgarian National Radio]] (BNR), and the [[Bulgarian Telegraph Agency]]. Bulgarian media have a record of unbiased reporting, although they are deemed potentially at risk of political influence due to the lack of legislation to protect them.<ref> {{cite web |author = Library of Congress – Federal Research Division |authorlink = Federal Research Division |title = Country Profile: Bulgaria |url = http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Bulgaria.pdf |publisher = Library of Congress |pages = 18, '''23''' |format = PDF |date = October 2006 |accessdate = 4 September 2009 |quote = Mass Media: In 2006 Bulgaria’s print and broadcast media generally were considered unbiased, although the government dominated broadcasting through the state-owned Bulgarian National Television (BNT) and Bulgarian National Radio (BNR) and print news dissemination through the largest press agency, the Bulgarian Telegraph Agency. [...]Human Rights: In the early 2000s, Bulgaria generally has been rated highly on the issue of human rights. However, some exceptions exist. Although the media have a record of unbiased reporting, Bulgaria’s lack of specific legislation protecting the media from state interference is a theoretical weakness. }} </ref> The written media have no legal restrictions and newspaper publishing is entirely liberal.<ref name="landscape">[http://www.ejc.net/media_landscape/article/bulgaria/ Media Landscape – Bulgaria] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722014211/http://www.ejc.net/media_landscape/article/bulgaria/|date=July 22, 2010 }}, European Journalism Centre</ref> The extensive freedom of the press means that no exact number of publications can be established, although some research put an estimate of around 900 print media outlets for 2006.<ref name="landscape"/> The largest-circulation daily newspapers include ''[[Dneven Trud]]'' and ''[[24 Chasa]]''.<ref name="landscape"/>
Non-printed media sources, such as [[television]] and [[radio]], are overseen by the Council for Electronic Media (CEM), an independent body with the authority to issue broadcasting licenses. Apart from a state-operated [[Bulgarian National Television|national television channel]], [[Bulgarian National Radio|radio station]] and the [[Bulgarian News Agency]], a large number of private television and radio stations exist. However, most Bulgarian media experience a number of negative trends, such as general degradation of media products, self-censorship and economic or political pressure.<ref name="media">[http://www.soros.org/initiatives/media/articles_publications/publications/financial-crisis-media-20091201/bulgaria-20091201.pdf Footprint of Financial Crisis in the Media, Bulgaria Country Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110503185125/http://www.soros.org/initiatives/media/articles_publications/publications/financial-crisis-media-20091201/bulgaria-20091201.pdf|date=May 3, 2011 }}, Open Society Institute, December 2009</ref> ''[[Slavi's Show]]'' and ''[[Gospodari Na Efira]]'' are among the most popular TV programs, both having more than 1,000,000 views per show.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120628220950/http://www.slusham.com/20-te-nay-gledani-predavaniya-sa-po-btv-bez-i.html 20-те най-гледани предавания са по bTV, без изключение!], slusham.com, January 2010</ref>
Internet media are growing in popularity due to the wide range of available opinions and viewpoints, lack of censorship and diverse content.<ref name="media"/>
<!--==History==--> ==Legislative framework== The main legislative base is the 1998 Radio and Television Act, amended several times since. Many issues still persist in the field<ref>e.g. "lack of sufficient guarantees for the independence of the regulatory body, insufficient expert knowledge and professionalism of the regulatory body, lack of transparency of the licensing procedures, lack of transparency of the ownership, issues related to the ways of funding and spending the sums which the Bulgarian National Television and the Bulgarian National Radio receive from the state budget, etc." Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_198 Bulgaria #Media Legislation], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref> The EU 2007 Audiovisual Media Services Directive was transposed in Bulgarian law in 2010, including the requirements for cultural diversity.<ref name=EJCmedia>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_198 Bulgaria #Media Legislation], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref>
[[Defamation]] in Bulgaria is decriminalised but punishable with large fines. Government officials have filed suits against journalists in the past, though courts tend to favour the latter and preserve [[press freedom]].<ref name=FH/> Legislation on [[access to information]] is fairly robust, although institutions may still improperly deny access and courts may act inconsistently on the issue. Media concentration is an issue and ownership transparency is lacking. A law was adopted in 2014 to restrict media ownership from offshore tax haven-based companies.<ref name=FH/>
===Status and self-regulation of journalists=== Journalists in Bulgaria work on decreasing salaries and face job insecurity, making work conditions more and more conducive to self-censorship and unethical practices.<ref name=FH/>
Violation of ethical and professional standards is often reported, particularly in the print press. Codes of Conduct for journalists have been drafted by several media and professional organizations after 1989, including the Union of Bulgarian Journalists, the Free Speech Forum and the Centre for Independent Journalism. In 2004 an Ethical Code of Bulgarian Media was drafted with support from EU experts, though it was rejected by part of the Bulgarian journalist scene.<ref name=EJCjourno>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_199 Bulgaria #Accountability systems], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref>
The Ethics Committee for the Print Media and the Ethics Committee for the Electronic Media were established in late 2005 after long debate, institutionalising mechanisms of self-regulation in the Bulgarian media sector.<ref name=EJCjourno/>
The [[New Bulgarian Media Group]] (NBMG), owned by [[Irina Krasteva]] and controlled by her son and MP [[Delyan Peevski]] has a long history of cross-partisan pro-governmental bias. In June 2014, a spat between Peevski and a bank owner spurred negative report on NBMG media that caused a [[bank run]] and forced the financial institute to temporarily close down.<ref name=FH/>
The [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Bulgaria)|2014 European elections]] and [[Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2014|parliamentary elections]] were closely followed by the media, but a large portion of the coverage consisted in unlabelled paid partisan content. Right-wing-affiliated print and broadcast media often carry [[hate speech]] against minorities and migrants.<ref name=FH/>
==Media outlets== The Bulgarian media panorama is pluralistic, although media outlets remain influenced by the political and economic interests of their owners and main advertisers. The shrinking advertising market has made the media more and more dependent on state advertising and other subsidies, in particular for small local media outlets.<ref name=FH/>
===Print media=== {{see also|List of newspapers in Bulgaria|List of magazines in Bulgaria}} Freedom of expression and free competition in the media market were introduced in Bulgaria after 1989. Newspaper publishing is not regulated by law, and no audit office or official record of the number of publications exist. Over 900 print media titles were estimated in 2007, but their number is today greatly reduced after the effects of the economic crisis. The nationally distributed dailies were 14 in 2009; circulation per capita is very low. <ref name=EJCprint>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_182 Bulgaria #Print Media], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref> Peevski's [[New Bulgarian Media Group]] (NBMG) and the competitor [[Media Group Bulgaria Holding]] own most of the private newspapers.<ref name=FH/>
The dominant form on the market is that of "hybrid tabloids", combining both quality press and tabloid features, including scandalous reporting, such as the dailies ''[[Trud (Bulgarian newspaper)|Trud]]'' and ''[[24 Chasa]]'', published by the German [[WAZ-Mediengruppe]]). The convergence is due to the failure in establishing quality broadsheets newspapers, leading instead popular dailies to extend their reach and occupy their niche. Other widely distributed newspapers include ''[[Standart (newspaper)|Standart]]'', [[Novinar]], ''Express'', ''Monitor'', and ''[[Telegraph (Bulgarian newspaper)|Telegraph]]'' - the latter being the only one to increase its circulation during the crisis, due to a lower price. ''[[Dnevnik (Bulgarian newspaper)|Dnevnik]]'' is deemed the most trustworthy on business and economy, but has a low circulation, together with ''Pari'', edited by the Swedish [[Bonnier Group]]. Political newspapers include ''Douma'', of the [[Bulgarian Socialist Party]], and ''Ataka'' (lit. "Attack"), of the homonymous [[Attack (political party)|nationalist party]].<ref name=EJCprint/>
To complement revenues from sales and advertisement, which most often do not arrive at coverning production costs, Bulgarian newspapers rely on contributions from business circles and political parties, hence opening up to avenues for political and commercial influences.<ref name=EJCprint/>
The regional print press include 10 dailies in the main towns of the country, as well as local publications coming out from once to three times per week.<ref name=EJCprint/>
Weeklies include the business-oriented ''[[Capital (newspaper)|Kapital]]'' and ''Banker'', and the popular 168 Chassa and Politika, together with the specialised Kultura. Yellow weeklies (''Show'', ''Weekend'', ''Galeria'') have recently entered the market. Magazines included around 100 titled in late 2009, including ''Tema'' and ''Praven Svyat''.<ref name=EJCprint/>
The Bulgarian print press market was totally dominated by the German WAZ group from 1996 onwards, both at national and local level. In December 2010 WAZ Mediagroup sold all its assets in Bulgaria to a joint venture between Austrian investors and local tycoons. Until then the company had owned the two largest daily newspapers Trud and 24 hours, the weekly newspaper 168 hours, and a large portfolio of magazines.
The ''New Bulgarian Media Group'', deemed close to the Turkish-minority [[Movement for Rights and Freedoms]] party emerged in 2007 and got own ''Monitor'', ''Express'', ''Telegraph'' (dailies), ''Politika'', ''Weekend'', ''Meridian Match'' (weeklies), the ''Borba'' newspaper and a publishing house (in the city of [[Veliko Turnovo]]).
<!--===Publishing===--> ===Radio broadcasting=== {{see also|List of radio stations in Bulgaria}} From 1935 to 1989 there was a state monopoly on radio broadcasts in Bulgaria. After liberalization, the market now features a high number of private, national and local radio stations.<ref name=EJCradio>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_183 Bulgaria #Radio], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref>
The sector is mainly controlled by four foreign groups: the [[Irish Communicorp]] Group, [[SBS Broadcasting]] Group (since 2007 part of [[ProSiebenSat.1 Media AG]]), US [[Emmis Communications]], and [[News Corporation]] Group (owned by [[Rupert Murdoch]]). A Bulgarian owner, Focus, joined them in late 2009. They overall control over 20 radio stations.<ref name=EJCradio/>
The two national-coverage radio stations are the [[Bulgarian National Radio]] (BNR), with two channels (''Horizont'' and ''Hristo Botev''), and the private [[Darik radio]]. BNP's ''Radio Bulgaria'' broadcasts abroad, as well as in 7 regional centres in the country.<ref name=EJCradio/>
===Television broadcasting=== {{Main|Television in Bulgaria}} Television in Bulgaria was [[Timeline of the introduction of television in countries|introduced in 1959]]. Although the [[Bulgaria]]n media market is small, it is one of the most vibrant and highly competitive in [[Central and Eastern Europe]]. At the turn of the century, global players such as [[News Corporation]], [[Modern Times Group]], [[Central European Media Enterprises]] and [[Fox Broadcasting Company]] briefly entered and consequently exited the Bulgarian TV market due to shrinking revenues, political pressure and the effect of the global recession of 2008.
Two of the leading TV stations, [[BTV (Bulgaria)|bTV]] and [[Nova television (Bulgaria)|Nova TV]], are foreign-owned. The third is the national public service broadcaster, [[Bulgarian National Television]]; BNT is deemed nonpartisan, but remains vulnerable to political interference from the government.<ref name=FH/> The fourth free-to-air TV network is [[Bulgaria On Air]], owned by Investor.BG (part of the controversial TIM Group of Varna).
Privately owned television channels started to appear immediately after the regime change. Most were associated with a cable television ([[CATV]]) network run by the same parent company. Around 1994-1995 private over-the-air broadcasters also appeared, but they usually only operated within a single area. [[Nova (Bulgarian TV)|Nova Television]] and [[7 Dni TV]] (''7 дни'', meaning ''7 days'') were two of the first such channels, available only in [[Sofia]]. After [[bTV (Bulgaria)|bTV]] took over [[Efir 2]]'s frequencies, another competition selected [[Nova Television (Bulgaria)|Nova Television]], already popular in cable networks around the country, as the second privately owned national channel in Bulgaria. The authorities currently refuse to license further analogue terrestrial channels (including local ones), until [[DVB-T]] broadcasting is started.
Switch off to Digital terrestrial television ([[DVB-T]]) was completed on 30 September 2013, after a 7-months simulcast period, with 96,2% of the population under DVB-T broadcasting coverage.<ref>http://dnes.dir.bg/news/televizia-tzifrovizatzia-izbori2013-tzifrov-signal-15122672?nt=4</ref>
===Cinema=== Public funds for the Bulgarian cinema have dried up after the socialist period. Bulgaria has produced three films and two documentaries per year with state subsidies, afforded under tender procedures. Sponsorships also support the Bulgarian film production.<ref name=EJCfilm>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_185 Bulgaria #Cinema], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref>
===Telecommunications=== {{Main|Telecommunications in Bulgaria}} The Bulgarian telecommunication market, now privatised, is shared mainly among three actors: [[A1 Bulgaria]] (owned by [[A1 Austria]] Austria Group), [[Telenor]] (owned by Czech PPF), and [[Vivacom]] (controlled by [[Russia's VTB]]). A1 Bulgaria and Telenor Bulgaria dominate the mobile market, while Vivacom retains dominance on the 2.3 million landlines.<ref name=EJCtlc>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_186 Bulgaria #Telecommunications], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref> Mobile phones in 2007 amounted to 9.87 million lines, with 110% penetration rate.
The telephony system features an extensive but antiquated telecommunications network inherited from the Soviet era; quality has improved; the Bulgaria Telecommunications Company's fixed-line monopoly terminated in 2005 when alternative fixed-line operators were given access to its network; a drop in fixed-line connections in recent years has been more than offset by a sharp increase in mobile-cellular telephone use fostered by multiple service providers; the number of cellular telephone subscriptions now exceeds the population.
===Internet=== {{Main|Internet in Bulgaria}} Internet access reached 55% of the population in 2014. Online media are more and more used as means of information, and social media have often used as a mobilisation tool.<ref name=FH/> *[[Top-level domain]]s: [[.bg]]<ref name=CIAWFB-Bulgaria-2014>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bu.html "Communications: Bulgaria"], ''World Factbook'', U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, 28 January 2014. Retrieved 1 February 2014.</ref> and [[.бг]]. <small>(proposed, Cyrillic)</small> *[[List of countries by number of Internet users|Internet users]]: **3.9 million users, 72nd in the world; 55.1% of the population, 74th in the world (2012);<ref name=NIUCalc>Calculated using penetration rate and population data from [https://www.census.gov/population/international/data/idb/rank.php "Countries and Areas Ranked by Population: 2012"], Population data, International Programs, U.S. Census Bureau, retrieved 26 June 2013</ref><ref name=ITU-IndividualsUsingTheInternet>[http://www.itu.int/en/ITU-D/Statistics/Documents/statistics/2013/Individuals_Internet_2000-2012.xls "Percentage of Individuals using the Internet 2000-2012"], International Telecommunications Union (Geneva), June 2013, retrieved 22 June 2013</ref> **3.4 million users, 63rd in the world (2009);<ref name=CIAWFB-Bulgaria-2014/> **1.9 million users (2007). *[[List of countries by number of broadband Internet subscriptions|Fixed broadband]]: 1.2 million subscriptions, 52nd in the world; 17.6% of population, 53rd in the world (2012).<ref name=NIUCalc/><ref name="FixedBroadbandITUDynamic2012">[http://www.itu.int/ITU-D/ICTEYE/Reporting/DynamicReportWizard.aspx "Fixed (wired)-broadband subscriptions per 100 inhabitants 2012"], Dynamic Report, ITU ITC EYE, [[International Telecommunication Union]]. Retrieved on 29 June 2013.</ref> *[[List of countries by number of broadband Internet subscriptions|Wireless broadband]]: 2.8 million, 55th in the world; 40.3% of the population, 41st in the world (2012).<ref name="MobleBroadbandITUDynamic2012">[http://www.itu.int/ITU-D/ICTEYE/Reporting/DynamicReportWizard.aspx "Active mobile-broadband subscriptions per 100 inhabitants 2012"], Dynamic Report, ITU ITC EYE, [[International Telecommunication Union]]. Retrieved on 29 June 2013.</ref> *[[List of countries by number of Internet hosts|Internet hosts]]: **976,277 hosts, 47th in the world (2012);<ref name=CIAWFB-Bulgaria-2014/> **513,470 (2008). *[[List of countries by IPv4 address allocation|IPv4]]: 4.2 million addresses allocated, 0.1% of the world total, 589.7 addresses per 1000 people, 51st in the world (2012).<ref>[http://www.countryipblocks.net/country-blocks/select-formats/ Select Formats] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120409181609/http://www.countryipblocks.net/country-blocks/select-formats/|date=April 9, 2012 }}, Country IP Blocks. Accessed on 2 April 2012. Note: Site is said to be updated daily.</ref><ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2119.html Population], [[The World Factbook]], [[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]. Accessed on 2 April 2012. Note: Data are mostly for 1 July 2012.</ref> <!--===Internet censorship and surveillance===-->
==Media Organisations== ===Media agencies=== The public media agency in Bulgaria is the [[Bulgarian News Agency]] (BTA), established in 1898 and regulated by a 1994 Statute. it serves all media in the country. Private web-based news agencies include ''Focus'' (now also a player on the radio market). <ref name=EJCnews>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_193 Bulgaria #News agencies], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref>
===Trade unions=== The [[Union of Publishers in Bulgaria]] (UPB) represents many owners of newspapers, magazines and books, though not all of them. <ref name=EJCtu>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_194 Bulgaria #Trade unions], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref>
The [[Association of the Bulgarian Broadcasters]] (ABBRO) represents the interests of the radio and television industry, and includes 60 companies representing 160 licensed radio and TV stations (2007 data).<ref name=EJCtu/>
The [[Union of Bulgarian Journalists]], stemming from its socialist roots, did not manage to establish itself as a professional organisation to protect journalists' interests.<ref name=EJCtu/>
NGOs in the media sector, dealing with media freedom and professionalisation of journalism, include Access to Information Program, Media Development Centre, Centre for Independent Journalism.<ref name=EJCtu/>
===Regulatory authorities=== In lack of any specific law on the printed media, there is not any specific regulatory or supervisory body either.
The Council for Electronic Media (CEM), established by the 1998 Radio and Television Act, checks compliance with regulations about advertising, sponsorship, copyright, protection of youth and minors, and considers violation complaints brought by experts and citizens. Five of its members are elected by Parliament, four are named by the President. Its independence from political and corporate pressures remains a matter of debate, and several of its actions have been controversial.<ref name=EJCreg>Vesela Tabakova, [http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria#link_200 Bulgaria #Regulatory authority], ''EJC Media Landscapes'', circa 2010</ref> The CEM is deemed as subject to multiple political and economic pressures.<ref name=FH/>
==Censorship, self-censorship, soft-censorship and media freedom== Bulgaria scores as "partly free" in [[Freedom House]]'s 2015 report, with a total score of 38.<ref name=FH>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/bulgaria Bulgaria] 2015 report</ref> In [[Reporters Without Borders]]' World Press Freedom Index, Bulgaria is ranked 106th, with a score of 32.91; in the region, Bulgaria comes after [[Greece]] (91st) and right before [[Montenegro]] (114th) and [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] (117th). Its score is on a steady downward path since the early 2000s (it was 34th on 158 in 2003).<ref>[[Reporters Without Borders]], [https://index.rsf.org/#!/index-details/BGR World Press Freedom Index] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419161741/http://index.rsf.org/|date=2016-04-19 }} 2015, Bulgaria</ref>
According to a 2016 report of the [[World Association of Newspapers and News Publishers]] (WAN IFRA), prepared by the [[South East Europe Media Organisation]] (SEEMO), the independence and pluralism of Bulgaria's media has eroded steadily over the past decade.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2016|title=Curbing Media, Crippling Debate: Soft Censorship in Bulgaria|url=http://www.wan-ifra.org/sites/default/files/field_article_file/SC%20Bulgaria%20final%202016%20%282%29.pdf|journal=WAN IFRA Soft censorship report series|publisher=World Association of Newspapers and News Publishers (WAN IFRA)|volume=|pages=|access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> In Bulgaria, media freedom and freedom of expression are increasingly constrained despite constitutional guarantees and right to access public information protected by the [[Access to public information in Bulgaria|Law on Access to Public Information]].<ref name=":0" />
According to WAN IFRA, Bulgarian authorities are increasingly employing tools of "[[soft censorship]]" to dominate and influence the country's media and limiting access to information and informed policy debate.<ref name=":0" /> Soft censorship, or indirect censorship, is defined as any official actions aiming at influencing media output, short of legal or extralegal bans, direct censorship, or physical attacks on media outlets and media professionals. These forms of indirect censorship include selective and partisan allocation of funds and advertising, as well as biased application of regulations and allocation of licenses, which can influence editorial content but also affect media outlets' sustainability.<ref name=":0" />
One of the main tool leading to official soft censorship in Bulgaria is, according to WAN IFRA, biased state funding for media. Allocation of advertising and subsidies are opaque and non transparent. The situation has deteriorated due to the financial crisis which resulted in an increased dependency on government funding and in media content which avoid any criticism against government and official actions.<ref name=":0" />
Many journalists cannot report in an impartial way and many are unwilling to openly speak about soft censorship as they fear of losing their jobs.<ref name=":0" />
Most media which are not controlled by the state, are in the hands of businesses with close ties to the governmental structures. [[Transparency of media ownership in Bulgaria|Transparency of media ownership]] is poor, but media ownership can be connected to a handful of leading political and business interests. Media owners and journalists know that in such a context critical coverage of people in government and public institutions the control or influence the allocation of funds may lead to the denial or withdrawal of such support, thus putting in danger their financial viability. Self-censorship may be necessary for economic survival.<ref name=":0" />
According to the 2016 WAN IFRA’s report, there are fewer physical attacks on journalists, although different threats are still reported. Much more common is use of libel and defamation lawsuits to intimidate and influence journalists or media outlets that not self-censor. Even though imprisonment for liberal and defamation was abolished in 1999, still they remain criminal offenses under Bulgarian criminal code. Convictions grounded in such cases are few, but the concrete possibility of prosecution entails a chilling effect on active, open and critical reporting.<ref name=":0" />
Pressures and intimidations on journalists are widespread, giving rise to [[self-censorship]]. Police also sometime questions media professionals about their activities. High-level politicians often display intolerance towards media criticism. Impunity for crimes against journalists remains the norm.<ref name=FH/> A June 2013 survey of 150 Bulgarian journalists by the Bulgarian affiliate of the [[Association of European Journalists]] remarked that 80% of them reported the existence of undue pressures and 60% said that internal pressures had distorted editorial contents.<ref name=pace/>
*In July 2012 in [[Varna]] a journalist for [[Dnevnik (Bulgaria)|Dnevnik]] and [[Capital (Bulgaria)|Capital]] <!-- Spas Spasov--> received threats by mail against his investigatives reports on corruption in local building projects.<ref name=pace>Parliamentary Assembly of the [[Council of Europe]], [http://www.cfom.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/PACE-HORSLEY-FINAL-2014-REPORT-AAC-25_14-Flego-protection-of-media-freedom-18-June.pdf The Protection of media freedom in Europe].Background report prepared by Mr William Horsley, special representative for media freedom of the [[Association of European Journalists]]</ref> *In 2013, an investigative journalist <!-- Hristo Hristov --> reported several threats to his life and safety to the police, linked to his investigations on the files and crimes of the former communist State Security Agency.<ref name=pace/> *In April 2014 the car of a TV host <!-- Genka Shikerova --> was set on fire for the second time in a year.<ref name=FH/> *In June 2014 two journalists who were taking pictures were threatened and attacked by politician [[Kiril Rashkov]] and two of his aides.<ref name=FH/>
==Concentration of media ownership and media pluralism== {{See also|Transparency of media ownership in Bulgaria}} ===Overview=== Concentration of media, both in terms of ownership and audience, is very high in Bulgaria.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://monitor.cmpf.eui.eu/results-2014/bulgaria/|title=Media Pluralism Monitor. Bulgaria 2014|last=|first=|date=June 2014|website=Monitor.cmpf.eui.eu|publisher=Centre for Media Pluralism and Media Freedom (CMPF)|access-date=20 March 2017}}</ref> Except for the Public Service Media, no media-specific legislation regulates media ownership concentration and the issue falls within the scope of the general competition law.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.balcanicaucaso.org/eng/Areas/Bulgaria/Media-concentration-and-media-ownership-in-Bulgaria-156381|title=Media concentration and media ownership in Bulgaria|last=Dimitrova|first=Svetla|date=17 October 2014|website=Balcanicaucaso.org|publisher=Osservatorio Balcani Caucaso Transeuropa|access-date=20 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> The Law on Radio and Television establishes only a general principle that a media licensing application must comply with the competition protection legislation. However, according to experts, this general provision proves to be inadequate.<ref name=":1" /> The Constitutional Court recognised media pluralism as an intrinsic part of media freedom, however “the principle of media pluralism is not respected in practice”.<ref name=":0" />
According to the [[Media Pluralism Monitor]] one of the major problems is the lack of effective legal remedies against media concentrations.<ref name=":0" /> Concern over concentration of media ownership in Bulgaria have also been raised by the [[European Commission]] in the first EU Anti-Corruption report which found out that media ownership in Bulgaria is increasingly concentrated, thus compromising editorial independence.<ref name=":0" />
In a nutshell, there are two main obstacles for the effective reduction of media concentrations in Bulgaria: non-transparent media ownership and the lack of media-specific legislation regulating media concentration. These obstacles cannot be removed without political will for this.<ref name=":1" />
===Legal framework=== Unlike a number of European states, in Bulgaria there are not special rules concerning the supervision of mergers and acquisitions in the media sector. This supervision aims at ruling out the possibility that a media business or person has an excessive interest in one or more media sectors.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=2015|title=Media ownership in Bulgaria: state of play and challenges|url=http://www.csd.bg/artShow.php?id=17518|journal=Center for the Study of Democracy|volume=Policy Brief No. 49|pages=|access-date=20 March 2017|via=}}</ref>
There are no provisions on media concentration in the Radio and Television Act applying to this media sector. As for print media, the sector is not regulated by law so there are no rules related to competition either. Issues related to concentration of ownership in the sector of digital media have not been discussed yet (2016).<ref name=":2" />
Media fall under the regulation of the Commission for the Protection of Competition (CPC) which is in charge of overseeing concentration among undertakings, prohibiting anti-competitive agreements, decisions and practices, as well as abuse of dominant position.<ref name=":2" /> The Commission defines market concentration and the exemptions from it. Businesses are obliged by law to report to the Commission in case their income exceeds a certain threshold. In such cases the Commission allows concentration if it does not lead to the establishment or increasing of a dominant position, which would significantly prevent competition in the relevant market.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=2016|title=A comparative analysis of media freedom and pluralism in the EU Member States|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2016/571376/IPOL_STU(2016)571376_EN.pdf|journal=Directorate-General for Internal Policies. Policy Department Citizens' Rights and Constitutional Affairs|chapter=|publisher=European Parliament (EP)|volume=|pages=|access-date=20 March 2017|via=}}</ref> In case of failure to report, or of concentration prohibited by the Commission, it may impose sanctions.<ref name=":3" />
In 2010, a new draft law on electronic media was discussed and the Commission for the Protection of Competition issued an opinion assessing the compliance of the proposal with the Protection of Competition Act. The Commission stated that in evaluating the risk of concentration it relies solely on an economic analysis, checking only the market share of the respective media, as well as audience share and advertising market share.<ref name=":2" /> The Commission does not take into consideration factors like the potential impact of the concentration on media content and the public significance of such impact.<ref name=":2" /> It thus observed that specific regulatory considerations regarding the media market, such as the need to guarantee pluralism and freedom of expression, are not taken into account by the Commission itself when overseeing concentrations.<ref name=":2" />
The case law of the regulatory authority regarding media concentration in Bulgaria clearly shows that further regulation and supervision are needed in order to guarantee that non-market principles, such as media pluralism, are taken into consideration in assessing transactions falling under competitive law. According to experts, effective measures for ensuring media pluralism should not be limited to self-regulation measures, but include the introduction of a body in charge of conducting non-economic analysis to assess the influence of media outlets.<ref name=":2" /> However, such measures are not endorsed on political level.<ref name=":2" />
===Broadcast sector=== In Bulgaria, the only legal explicit restrictions on media ownership is enshrined in the Law on Radio and Television, adopted in 1998 and amended several times since then. The Law was elaborated with the aim of regulating the market of broadcast media.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Media ownership and its impact on media independence and pluralism|last=Petković|first=Brankica|publisher=Peace Institute, Institute for Contemporary Social and Political Studies|year=2004|isbn=961-6455-26-5|location=Ljubljana,|pages=|chapter=Bulgaria}}</ref> Although the Law was not conceived specifically to address the issue of concentration, it includes restrictions on cross-ownership, pertaining only to national broadcasters.<ref name=":4" /> According to the law, licenses cannot be awarded to legal persons (or persons related to legal persons) which already possess licenses for local radio or television stations. This amendment was introduced after discovering cases of local operators acquiring licenses for national broadcasting. The Law also stipulates that national operators cannot become owners of local and regional stations. It also requires applicants to declare that they do not hold stakes, shares or other rights of participation in radio and television broadcasters above the threshold set by anti-trust legislation.<ref name=":4" />
The law regulates the operation of Bulgarian broadcasters and contains some provisions restricting broadcast licenses and regulates the registration of cable programmes.<ref name=":4" /> Several provisions aim at protecting the media environment from the entry of dubious capital. For instance, the Law establishes that businesses connected with insurance services are ineligible for applying for a broadcast license. This provision is the result of a specific feature of the Bulgarian economy, where certain insurance companies born out of structures related to the previous regime's security services sector.<ref name=":4" /> However, in practice, due to the weakness of the Bulgarian media market which is unable to sustain the broadcast and print media, the opportunities for the entry of suspicious capitale into the media sphere have recently increased.<ref name=":4" /> Also, the law excludes from holding a license of a broadcast media telecommunications operators placed in a monopoly situation on the market (i.e. the state telecommunications company Bulgarian Telecommunications Company) and advertising agencies or companies including partners or shareholders having interests in the advertisement market.<ref name=":4" />
When applying for a license in the broadcasting sector, the applicant is required to submit a declaration showing who the owners are and what their shares are, including document showing the origin of the capital for the last three years. Also, the application should include a list of media enterprises in which the persons are shareholders or partners.<ref name=":4" />
===Press distribution=== Tendencies towards concentration characterise the area of press distribution as well. Some of the factors contributing to this concern the possibility for a publisher to be a distributor at the same time; the aggregation of ownership in non-transparent way; and political connections and dependencies influencing the sector. A dominant position in this sector impedes the fair distribution of small publishers' works.<ref name=":2" /> In 2011, the Commission for the Protection of Competition carried out an analysis on the press distribution sector. It found out that in the period from 2009 to 2011 there was a pooling of the distributors on the market aiming at optimising costs exploit the advantages of economies of scale and scope. Such integration impeded the entry of new actors on the market and led to market concentration.<ref name=":2" />
===The case of the ''New Media Group''=== Media concentration has been widely debated in Bulgaria since the 1990s. After the change from Communism to the market economy, the country faced the issue of concentration: the monopoly positions of the state media were replaced by the domination of several private media groups.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3" /> In the 1990s the problem affected in particular the print sector: two most influential newspapers at that time - ''Trud'' and ''24 hours'' - were purchased by the ''WAZ Group''. The group dominated the Bulgarian media market until the late 2000s.<ref name=":3" /> In the late 2000s, the creation and rapid grow of the ''New Media Group'' were seen again as a case of media ownership concentration in the sector of print and online media.<ref name=":3" /> At stakes there was the group’s links with politics and a bank.<ref name=":3" /> The group purchased local media, thus acquiring a dominant position in the local media market and in print media distribution. According to some estimates, the company gained a 70-80% share in the print media distribution market.<ref name=":3" /> The case of the ''New Media Group'' lead to public debate in 2001 that forced the Commission on the Protection of Competition to make a sectoral analysis of the concentration in the print media distribution market. The study found that the concentration in 2009-2011 constituted an obstacle to new competitors wishing to enter the market . The Commission also concluded that there was a lack of transparent rules in the field. However, it issued a permission for such concentration on the basis that it would not establish or increase a dominant position in the distribution market.<ref name=":3" />
===Concentration of media ownership in practice=== According to the [[Media Pluralism Monitor]], "concentration of media ownership is very high".<ref name=":0" /> The top 4 major owners in the broadcasting sector have an aggregated market share (based on advertising revenue only) of 93.35%. The top 4 major owners of daily newspapers reach an aggregated market share of 79.7%. As for Internet Service Providers (ISPs), they have an estimated market share which is above 50%.<ref name=":0" /> Concentration trends are also present in terms of audience and readership whose concentration is "very high" according to the Media Pluralism Monitor.<ref name=":0" /> In television, the top 4 major owners have an audience share that is above 70%; as for the radio sector, the aggregated share of the top 4 major owners is 83.16%. The top 4 major newspaper owners have an estimated readership share between 25 to 49%, and the subscription share of the top 4 ISPs is estimated to be above 50%.<ref name=":0" />
===Political and economic influence on media owners=== In Bulgaria, there are significant links between media owners and other actors operating in the economic landscape.<ref name=":3" /> According to expert Nelly Ognyanova, there are unregulated links between media, money and power.<ref name=":1" /> This fact became publicly known following a joint access to information request submitted by 11 biggest newspapers in 2010, which revealed that a media group owning newspapers, internet outlets and a TV station borrowed large amounts of money from a big bank, the ''Corporate Trade Bank''. Also, the information disclosed showed that the same bank hosted a considerable amount of budget money of several ministers as well as bank accounts of relevant state-owned companies operating in the field of energy, public transport, defence and information service.<ref name=":3" /> The owner of such media group, Delyan Peevsky, also runs businesses in other sectors, such as construction, tobacco and newspapers distribution. Moreover, his businesses are allegedly involved in big public procurements.<ref name=":3" /> The group is also connected with the political party, the ''Movement for Rights and Freedoms'' (DPS) which has been influential for many years.<ref name=":3" /> Mr. Peevsky is the son of Irena Krasteva, the owner of many of the print media outlets within the ''New Media Group''. Bulgarian press revealed the existence of connections between the ''New Media Group'' and political parties and other businesses.<ref name=":3" /> This is not the only case of political influence over the media in Bulgaria. For instance, there are some media which are officially owned by political figures or parties, a case that is not prohibited by law in Bulgaria.<ref name=":3" />
<!-- ===Attacks and threats against journalists=== ===Political interferences=== ===Civil defamation lawsuits=== ===Cyber-attacks=== ===Smear campaigns=== -->
==State Funding== {{Expand section|date=November 2017}} The communication campaigns on EU funds turned out to be one of the funding sources for the Bulgarian media. The budget on advertising for the period 2007-2014 was 84.3 mln. EUR (165 mln. BGN). A detailed distribution of the funds between outlets isn't available as the contracts between ministries and media were conducted by advertising agencies and other intermediaries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Curbing Media, Crippling Debate|url=http://www.seemo.org/assets/pdf/soft-censorship-bulgaria.pdf|publisher=WAN-IFRA World Association of Newspapers and News Publishers|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==See also== *[[Transparency of media ownership in Bulgaria]] *[[Access to public information in Bulgaria]]
{{Bulgaria topics|state=collapsed}} {{Europe topic|Media of}}
[[Category:Media in Bulgaria| ]]

{{For|the British Secret Intelligence Service|MI6}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox Website |name = MI6-HQ.com |url = http://www.MI6-HQ.com |commercial = No |type = Information & Media |owner = MI6-HQ.com }} '''MI6-HQ.com''' is a media-website dedicated to the people, places and world of [[James Bond]], providing daily updates on the subject. == About == MI6-HQ.com (formerly '''MI6.co.uk''', which subsequently redirects to CommanderBond.net) publishes original, in-depth articles and intercepts a comprehensive collection of news headlines involving all aspects of the world of James Bond, including news on the actors (past, present and future), the production team, film news and commercial product tie-ins. As well as news from the Bond films, MI6-HQ.com is host to a series of portals for both literary and filmic coverage of an encyclopaedic nature. The website is probably best known for its range of exclusive interviews with influential members of the James Bond world, including [[Charlie Higson]][http://www.MI6-HQ.com/sections/articles/interview_charlie_higson_yb1f_bookfive.php3 MI6 – The Home of James Bond – In Conversation With Charlie Higson] (''[[Young Bond]]'' writer), [[David Hedison]][http://www.MI6-HQ.com/sections/articles/interview_david_hedison.php3 MI6 – The Home of James Bond – David Hedison Interview] (two time Felix Leiter actor), [[Jeffery Deaver]]{{cite web|title=Jeffery Deaver Exclusive Interview|url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/interview_jeffery_deaver1.php3|publisher=MI6-HQ.com|accessdate=31 August 2011}} (author of ''[[Carte Blanche (novel)|Carte Blanche]]'', a Bond [[continuation novel]]) and [[Christopher Wood (writer)|Christopher Wood]],[http://www.MI6-HQ.com/sections/articles/interview_christopher_wood.php3 MI6 – The Home of James Bond – Christopher Wood Interview] screenwriter for ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]''. ==Events== In 2005 MI6, together with [[Cinema Retro]] and BondStars.com, put together a screening of the Bond film ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' to celebrate the film's 40th anniversary.{{cite web | url = http://www.MI6-HQ.com/sections/articles/events_thunderball_40th_report.php3 | title = Thunderball 40th Anniversary Event Report}} Dave Worrall, Lee Pfeiffer (Journalists and Cinema Retro publishers), Gareth Owen (author) and the founders of MI6 hosted the event. As well as the screening of the 1965 film, the event hosted a book signing with Sir Christopher Frayling and question and answer sessions with [[Ken Adam]], [[Molly Peters]], [[George Leech (actor)|George Leech]], [[Martine Beswick]], [[Earl Cameron (actor)|Earl Cameron]] and [[Norman Wanstall]]. In 2010, MI6 published an exclusive copy of the "lost" ''[[Per Fine Ounce]]'' extract by acclaimed South African novelist [[Geoffrey Jenkins]]. It was released by the Jenkins estate and gives fans a glimpse into what might have been had [[Ian Fleming Publications|Glidrose]] accepted the manuscript.[http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/literary_per_fine_ounce_extract.php3 MI6 – The Home of James Bond – Per Fine Ounce – Exclusive Extract] == Media association == Since its foundation, MI6 has been a trustworthy resource for media organisations across the world. It has been frequently cited as the best James Bond website by media outlets such as ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' and ''[[The Times]]''. Press organisations and websites who've been assisted by MI6 include: * ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine{{cite news | url =http://www.time.com/time/sampler/article/0,8599,443261,00.html | title = That Old Feeling: Apres-War Movies | work=Time}} * ''Entertainment Weekly''{{cite news | title = 25 Essential Fansites | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20167049_17,00.html | accessdate=22 December 2007 | work=Entertainment Weekly}} * [[Times Online]]{{cite news | title = The 10 best fan websites | url = http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/the_web/article7092677.ece | accessdate=11 April 2010 | work=The Times | location=London | first=Mike | last=Peake | date=11 April 2010}} * [[MTV]]{{cite web | url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2007/10/02/the-dailies-october-2-2007/ | title = Bond 22 to Film in Panama }} * [[Reuters]]{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSTRE4AC3NK20081113?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0|title=Tough Bond girl divides fans, reignites debate | agency=Reuters | date=13 November 2008}} * ''The Times''{{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article624858.ece | title = Bond's new love interest never says never again | work=The Times | location=London | first=Jack | last=Malvern | date=4 November 2006 | accessdate=12 May 2010}} ==See also== *[[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]], the British Secret Intelligence Service *[[James Bond]], fictional character *[[Ian Fleming]], author *''[[Skyfall]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.mi6-hq.com MI6-HQ.com] {{James Bond}} [[Category:British websites]] [[Category:Community websites]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]] [[Category:James Bond]] [[Category:Film websites]]

'''Minutemen''' in '''comics''' may refer to:
* [[Minutemen (Watchmen)]], a team of comic book characters found in Alan Moore's ''Watchmen'' * ''[[Before Watchmen: Minutemen]]'', a comic book series by Darwyn Cooke * [[Minute-Man]], a comic book superhero appearing in Fawcett Comics and DC Comics * [[The Minutemen (100 Bullets)]], fictional characters in the 100 Bullets comic series
==See also== * [[Minutemen (disambiguation)]]
{{SIA|comics}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox website | name = Mperience s.r.l. | logo = http://www.mperience.com/images/logotop.png | company_type = Private | type = Cinema, literature, art; Social media Internet Forum, Recommender System | foundation = December 2009 | founder = | location_city = Rome | location_country = Italy | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Paolo Baronci - Co-founder, CEO
Francesco Carusi - Co-founder, CTO
Guido Gigante - Co-founder, Chief Scientific Officer | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | url = http://www.mperience.com | screenshot = | caption = | language = English | advertising = | registration = | launch_date = | current_status = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Mperience''' is a [[social media]] platform about [[film|cinema]], [[literature]] and [[art]] ([[painting]], [[sculpture]], [[photography]], and [[architecture]]). It was launched in April 2010 and is currently in [[Software testing|public alpha]]. == Description == ''Mperience'' provides to the public a [[database]] of about 54000 movies, 28000 books and 18000 artists on which is built a semantic [[recommender system]].[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] Italy, July 2010 Each [[movie]], [[book]] and [[artist]] is accessible via a [[web page]], presenting basic information and recommendations for related videos and related items. [[End-user|Users]] can browse these pages through themes and emotions (e.g., “myths and philosophy” or “journey of rediscovery”) that connect different items. The [[Website|site]] allows users to share opinions about cinema, literature and art by mingling text with videos and images. The resulting pages are named ''Memes'' on the site, supposedly with reference to [[Richard Dawkins]]’ concept of [[meme]]. == Technology == ''Mperience'' [[recommender system]] is based on both [[natural language processing]] and [[machine learning]] [[algorithm]]s. Algorithms include variations of [[restricted Boltzmann machine]], [[singular value decomposition]], [[K-nearest neighbor algorithm|''k''-nearest neighbors]], and [[Bayesian network]]s. [[Semantic search|Semantic]] algorithms allow the extraction of relevant passages (“themes & emotions”) {{cite web | title=Terminology extraction from unstructured texts, collaboration with the Department of Informatics at La Sapienza University |url=http://w3.uniroma1.it/dipinfo/dbinfo/verbali/cdd290110.pdf|accessdate=2010-06-24}} from the descriptions of items and the [[computation]] of [[Semantic similarity|similarity]] between these texts. ''Mperience'' credits [[Wikipedia]] and [[Freebase (database)|Freebase]] as its primary sources of [[Ontology (information science)|ontological information]] about movies, books, and artists. == History == ''Mperience'' was founded in December 2009 and raised $230.000 in [[seed funding]] from [[private investors]]. In January 2010, the company was one of the finalists at the Start-up Initiative, the [[Start-up company|start-up]] competition organized by [[Intesa Sanpaolo|Intesa-San Paolo]] [[Bank|banking group]],Il Mondo, 12 February 2010 and in March 2010 was invited at SMAU computer [[Exhibition|expo]] for the exhibition "Percorsi dell'Innovazione" (Innovation Paths).{{cite web | title=MPerience at SMAU, Percorsi dell'Innovazione |url= http://roma.smau.it/article/articleview/1942/ |accessdate=2010-06-25}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.mperience.com/ Mperience Official Website] [[Category:Alpha software]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]] [[Category:Film websites]] [[Category:Entertainment Internet forums]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Panther Games Pty Ltd | logo = Panther Games Pty Ltd company logo (gold).png | logo_size = 225px | caption = | type = [[Proprietary company]] | foundation = 1985 | founder = David O'Connor | location = [[Canberra]], [[Australia]] | key_people = David O'Connor, President
Paul Scobell, UI Developer | industry = [[Video game industry]]
[[Interactive entertainment]] | products = ''[[Trial of Strength]]''
''[[Fire-Brigade: The Battle for Kiev - 1943|Fire Brigade]]''
''Airborne Assault: Conquest of the Aegean''
''[[Command Ops: Battles from the Bulge]]'' | revenue = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | homepage = [http://panthergames.com/ www.panthergames.com] }} '''Panther Games Pty Ltd''' ('''Panther Games''') is an [[Australia]]n [[video game developer|games developer]], best known for the WWII [[Airborne Assault]] and [[Command Ops]] PC video game series. Panther Games specialises in developing operational level [[Wargaming|wargames]] for the [[Wargame (video games)|PC Wargame]] market. ==History== Panther Games was founded in 1985{{cite web | url = http://www.mobygames.com/company/panther-games-pty-ltd | title = Moby Games: Panther Games Pty Ltd profile | publisher=[[MobyGames]] | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }} by David O’Connor in [[Canberra]], [[Australia]]. In the early years Panther Games initially focused on developing and producing [[board games]] and released three titles in the mid 80’s, ''[[Trial of Strength]]'', ''[[Shanghai Trader]]'' and ''[[Warlords: China in Disarray, 1916 – 1950|Warlords]]''.{{cite web | url = http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/8208/trial-of-strength | title = Board Game Geek: Trial of Strength | publisher=[[BoardGameGeek]] | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }}{{cite web | url = http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/796/shanghai-trader | title = Board Game Geek: Shanghai Trader | publisher=[[BoardGameGeek]] | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }}{{cite web | url = http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/7267/warlords-china-in-disarray-1916-1950 | title = Board Game Geek: Warlords China in Disarray 1916-1950 | publisher=[[BoardGameGeek]] | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }} However, the company shifted their focus to developing [[computer games]] in the late 1980s with the release of their first computer wargame, ''[[Fire-Brigade: The Battle for Kiev - 1943|Fire Brigade]]'', in 1988 on [[Macintosh|Mac]], [[DOS]], [[Atari]] and [[Amiga]].{{cite web | url = http://www.mobygames.com/game/fire-brigade-the-battle-for-kiev-1943 | title = Moby Games: Fire Brigade the battle for Kiev 1943 | publisher=[[MobyGames]] | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }} Fire Brigade currently forms part of the historical collection of software; hardwere; trade and promotional materials that document the history of [[Apple Inc.]] and its contributions to the computer industry and society. This collection is currently housed at [[Museum Victoria]], [[Melbourne]].Reg. No: HT 13672 {{cite web | url = http://museumvictoria.com.au/collections/items/1231526/apple-macintosh-software-game-fire-brigade-the-battle-for-kiev-1943-3-floppy-disk-1989 | title = Apple Macintosh Software Game - 'Fire Brigade The Battle for Kiev 1943', 3½" Floppy Disk, 1989 | publisher = [[Museum Victoria]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150215091928/http://museumvictoria.com.au/collections/items/1231526/apple-macintosh-software-game-fire-brigade-the-battle-for-kiev-1943-3-floppy-disk-1989 | archivedate = 15 February 2015 | df = dmy-all }} Following the success of Fire Brigade, Panther Games took a step into the mainstream games market with the releases of [[sci-fi]] adventure ''[[Alien Drug Lords]]'' and puzzle challenge game [[Cubit game|''Cubit'']] in 1991.{{cite web | url = http://hol.abime.net/3241 | title = Hall of Light - The database of Amiga Games: Alien Drug Lords: The Chyropian Connection | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }}{{cite web | url = http://hol.abime.net/3141 | title = Hall of Light - The database of Amiga Games: Cubit | accessdate = 2013-01-10 }} In 1996 Panther Games decided to return to its [[Wargame (video games)|wargame]] roots and instigated development of a new [[Real-time strategy|real-time computer game engine]] for a novel operational wargame series to be called Airborne Assault (AA).The use of a real-time engine without a hexagon grid for a wargame was novel as traditional computer wargames run on a turn-based system where there are dedicated phases for planning, movement and engagement. The AA engine (later rebranded Command Ops) allowed for planning, movement and engagement to be played in continues time and the hexagon grid was no longer needed to determine movement capabilities of units.{{cite web | url = http://www.wargamer.com/article/3161/Command-Ops:-Highway-to-the-Reich | title = THE GAME & THE THREE T’s: TRAVEL, TIME AND TRICKLE-DOWN | date=5 March 2012 | accessdate = 2013-01-11 | publisher=[[The Wargamer (website)|The Wargamer]] |first=John |last=Thompson }} Panther Games' AA game engine and the associated [[AI]] capabilities has notably been referenced in publications by Peter Perla at [[Center for Naval Analyses]] (CNA), Michael Peck at Defence News and the Digital Humanities at [[King's College London]].Perla, Peter P. & Markowitz, Michael C. (January, 2009) {{cite web | url = http://www.cna.org/sites/default/files/research/D0019256.A2.pdf | title = Wargaming Strategic Linkage | pages=93–94 | accessdate = 2013-01-12 | publisher=[[Center for Naval Analyses]]}}Peck, Michael (10 August 2010) {{cite web | url = http://www.defensenews.com/article/20100824/TSJ01/8240314/Battle-smarts | title = Battle smarts: Top-notch AI puts command sim ahead of the pack | accessdate = 2013-01-14 | publisher=Defencenews.com}}Peck, Michael (21 June 2012) {{cite web | url = http://www.defensenews.com/article/20120621/TSJ01/306210004/Game-Revie | title = Game Review: 'Highway to the Reich' | accessdate = 2013-01-12 | publisher=Defencenews.com}}Sabin, Philip (2010) {{cite web | url = http://dh2010.cch.kcl.ac.uk/academic-programme/abstracts/papers/html/ab-715.html#fnLink10 | title = Wargames in a Digital Age | accessdate = 2013-01-12 | publisher=Digital Humanities at [[King's College London]]}} The first title to be produced in the series was ''[[Airborne Assault: Red Devils over Arnhem]]'' (RDOA) and was released in 2002 through wargame publisher [[battlefront.com]].{{cite web | url = http://au.gamespot.com/airborne-assault-red-devils-over-arnhem/ | title = Gamespot AU: Airborne Assault Red Devils over Arnhem | publisher=[[GameSpot]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11 }} However, in Europe, Panther Games used a different publisher, [[CDV Software Entertainment AG]], and the title for the game was simply Airborne Assault.{{cite web | url = http://www.mobygames.com/game/windows/airborne-assault-red-devils-over-arnhem/cover-art/gameCoverId,34681/ | title = Moby Games: CDV cover art for Airborne Assault | publisher=[[MobyGames]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11 }} The second and third instalments of the AA series were released through a new publisher, [[Matrix Games]], with ''[[Airborne Assault: Highway to the Reich]]'' (HTTR) coming out in 2003 and ''[[Airborne Assault: Conquest of the Aegean]]'' (COTA) in 2006.{{cite web | url = http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=42980&tab=sysreqs | title = Allgame: Airborne Assault Highway to the Reich | publisher=[[Allgame]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.matrixgames.com/products/313/details/Conquest.of.the.Aegean | title = Matrix Games: Airborne Assault Conquest of the Aegean | publisher=[[Matrix Games]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11 }} In 2010, Panther Games rebranded their long running games series to Command Ops and released their latest title, ''[[Command Ops: Battles from the Bulge]]'' (BFTB).{{cite web | url = http://www.pcworld.com/article/197693/battles_from_the_bulge.html | title = Why PC Wargame Battles From The Bulge Costs So Much | date=1 June 2010 | accessdate = 2013-01-11 | publisher=[[PC World]] |first=Matt |last=Peckham }} In 2012, the first official [[expansion pack]] Panther Games has ever released came out titled, ''Command Ops: Highway to the Reich''. This is an expansion pack for BFTB and covers content from the original two AA games.{{cite web | url = http://www.matrixgames.com/products/421/details/Command.Ops:.Highway.to.the.Reich | title = Matrix Games: Command Ops Highway to the Reich | publisher=[[Matrix Games]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11 }} 18 October 2014, Panther Games in conjunction with [[Lock 'n Load (tabletop game)|Lock 'n Load publishing]] jointly announce Panther Games' move to Lock 'n Load publishing following the split between Panther games and Matrix Games. Following the announcement it was revealed Panther Games through Lock n' Load would be re-releasing Panther Games' successful 1985 board game [[Trial of Strength]] with a new edition. it would be the first time the board game has been re-released since its initial release in 1985. In addition, it was revealed Panther Games' new game engine, Command Ops 2, would be released through the publisher along with all subsequent data packs for the engine. This represented a new method of content delivery for the company.{{cite web | url = http://forums.lnlpublishing.com/threads/welcome-panther-games.867/ | title = Welcome Panther Games | publisher=[[Lock 'n Load (tabletop game)|Lock 'n Load]] | first= | last= | date=2014-10-18 | accessdate = 2015-07-31 }}{{cite web | url = http://grogheads.com/?p=6388 | title = Breaking News: Panther Games signs with LNLP | publisher=Grogheads | first= | last= | date=2014-10-20 | accessdate = 2015-07-31 }} June 2015, Command Ops 2 goes public beta and the "Commander Pack" consisting of all five modual data packs for Command Ops 2 goes on sale 16 June 2015. ===Professional services to the military=== Parallel to its commercial wargame development, Panther Games also provides [[professional services]] to the military. Simulation Australia (part of the Australian Department of innovation, Industry, Science and Research) describe Panther Games' [[professional services]] capabilities to include wargame design and development; [[artificial intelligence]]; user interface; [[Computer programming|programming]]; scenario development (including for [[JSAF]]); Puckstering (for [[JSAF]]) and a wide range of Analysis.{{cite web | url = http://directory.simulationaustralia.org.au/company/panther-games-pty-ltd/ | title = Panther Games | year=2012 | publisher=simulationaustralia.org.au | accessdate = 2013-01-14 }} In 2007, Panther Games was a team partner along with [[Booz Allen Hamilton]], Ball Solutions, [[Centre for Adult Education|CAE]] and Calytrix Technology in the successful Joint Decision Support and Simulations Centre (JDSSC) project for the [[Australian Department of Defence]].{{cite web | url = http://www.calytrix.com/news/newsitem/94/ | title = Calytrix Teams on JDSSC | date=22 March 2007 | publisher= Calytrix Technologies | accessdate = 2013-01-11 }} In 2009, Panther Games became an associate member of the joint Defence-Industry initiative, Rapid Prototyping, Development and Evaluation Program (RPDE).{{cite web | url = http://www.rpde.org.au/participants | title = RPDE Participants | publisher=RPDE | accessdate = 2013-01-14 }} In October 2010, Panther Games began a four-month scoping study for the Australian Defence Simulation Office (ADSO) to determine the Defence requirements for a course of action analyser simulation tool. ==Games== ===Board Games=== *''[[Trial of Strength]]'' (1985) *''Warlords: China in Disarray, 1916 – 1950'' (1986) *''Shanghai Trader'' (1986) ===Computer Games=== *''[[Fire-Brigade: The Battle for Kiev - 1943|Fire Brigade]]'' (1988) *''Alien Drug Lords'' (1991) *''Cubit'' (1991) *''Airborne Assault: Red Devils over Arnhem'' (2002) *''Airborne Assault: Highway to the Reich'' (2003) *''Airborne Assault: Conquest of the Aegean'' (2006) *''[[Command Ops: Battles from the Bulge]]'' (2010) **''[[Command Ops: Battles from the Bulge|Command Ops: Highway to the Reich]]'' (2012) – expansion to BFTB **''[[Command Ops: Battles from the Bulge|Command Ops: Battles for Greece]]'' (2013) - expansion to BFTB *''Command Ops 2'' (2015) **''Command Ops 2: Bastogne'' **''Command Ops 2: Foothills of the Gods'' **''Command Ops 2: Highway to the Reich'' **''Command Ops 2: Ride of the Valkyries'' **''Command Ops 2: The Cauldron'' ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://panthergames.com/|name=Panther Games Official Website}} *[http://directory.simulationaustralia.org.au/company/panther-games-pty-ltd/ Panther Games'] directory profile at Simulation Australia *[http://store.lnlpublishing.com/panther-games Panther Games LnL Products Home] *[http://lnlpublishing.com Lock 'n Load Publishing Home] [[Category:Companies established in 1985]] [[Category:Video game companies of Australia]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Modeling and simulation]] [[Category:Companies based in Canberra]]

[[File:Pop art polka dot wall (41021626251).jpg|right|thumb|Polka dots painted on a wall]] '''Polka dot paint''' is a [[paint]] which produces a [[polka dot]] pattern.
The paint is traditionally an impossible object, and the subject of a [[fool's errand]] prank played upon [[apprentice]]s in the decoration or construction trade, who are sent to obtain a bucket of polka-dot paint.<ref>''The Painter and Decorator'', Volume 73, 1959, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sO-fAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22polka+dot%22 p. 4]</ref><ref> Peter J. H. Petter-Bowyer, "Winds of Destruction: The Autobiography of a Rhodesian Combat Pilot", [https://books.google.com/books?id=akwPLOZMZYIC&pg=PA72 p. 72]</ref><ref>Richard Gordon Charman, ''The Learning Curve: My Story'', 2011, {{ISBN|0987060007}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3kcZlq_1kZsC&pg=PA78 p. 78] *''Quote:'' "Like all tradesmen, in all companies, the new apprentices were sent by them to the local hardware store <...> to get 'a left-handed hammer', 'a right-handed scredwriver', 'a box of r/h threaded holes', 'a tin of blue and yellow striped paint', 'a tin of black and white polka dot paint' <...> "</ref> A polka-dot paint effect has been produced in [[stage magic]], and in the 1950s a polychromatic paint was invented which produced a dotted effect when dry.
==Magic tricks== In the United States several [[magician (illusionist)|magician]]s invented a trick in which they demonstrating painting with polka-dot paint. Prior to the performance, an object is pre-painted in the desired pattern with an [[oil-based paint]] and then covered with white [[watercolor]] or [[whitewash]]. During the trick, a wet brush passed over the object removes the layer of watercolor, revealing the polka dots.
The truck was the subject of litigation between two [[stage magicians]], Harry Albacker and Paul Stadelman in 1950s. The defendant's defense was that the magic act was "old as hills", and hence in [[public domain]]. <ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19491101&id=EdcNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QWoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2454,31794&hl=en "Another Claims Spotted Pigment Invention As Local Magician Says In's 2 Other Tricks"], ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, November 1, 1949, page 3.</ref> <ref>"General News: Magic", by Bill Sachs, ''[[The Billboard]]'', January 14, 1950 [https://books.google.com/books?id=9vUDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT44 p. 47]</ref> Stadelman, in his turn was challenged by other magicians who claimed that he took the idea from the "[[barber's pole]] paint" trick. However Stadelman claimed it was actually he who invented the barber's pole paint trick in the first place.<ref name=b1950>"Magician Finds Public Ready For New Paint", ''The Bulletin'', March 3, 1950, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19500303&id=-2hYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cvcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6303,5615908&hl=en p. 9]</ref> Stadelman said that often after he performed this trick as paint dealers' conventions, he was getting letters from people who wanted to market this paint.<ref name=b1950/>
Another version of this trick involves colorless chemicals on the object which become colored after a reaction with another chemical on the brush.
==Real paint== In 1950 a product called "Plextone" by Maas & Walsdtein Co. was advertised, a finishing which is a single application produced "a network of interlaced but separate colors - a 'Polka Dot' paint".<ref>''Product Finishing'', vol 15, 1950, p. 110 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=y9o3AAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Polka+dot google snippet])</ref> In 1952 a John C. Zola patented (US 3811904 <ref>[https://www.google.com/patents/US3811904 "Novel coating compositions and their preparation - US 3811904 A".] *''Quote:'' "multi-color coating compositions of two or more phases consisting of at least one dispersed phase consisting of discrete globules or droplets of film-former and organic solvent, which dispersed phase is dispersed in a liquid organic dispersing medium. At least some of the dispersed globules are different in color from the dispersin'g medium" </ref>) polychromatic paint, technically described as "a multicolor paint from lacquer-based colorants suspended in water". The inventor was inspired by French painter [[Georges Seurat]], who created his [[impressionism|impressionist]] effects using small dots of paint. <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6zQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA50 "Dotting the Eyes"], ''The Rotarian'', July 1975, p. 50</ref> Sapolin Paints, Inc. of New York City sold "polka-dot paint" in a [[spray can]], which sprayed droplets of paint; the farther the can was from the surface the larger were the dots. <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=5t0DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA207 "On the Market for Do-It-Yourselfers"], ''[[Popular Mechanics]],'' March 1958, p. 207</ref>
==In popular culture== *In ''[[The Vanishing Private]]'' cartioon (1942), private [[Donald Duck]] tries to camouflage a cannon by painting it with red, green and yellow stripes, and black polka dots, from a single bucket.<ref>[https://www.mouseplanet.com/11667/Walt_Goes_to_War_Part_Two "Walt Goes to War: Part Two"], Jim Korkis, January 25, 2017, ''Mouse Planet''</ref> *Polka-dot [[nail polish]] and [[marker pen]]s incorporate glitter or non-glitter colored particles to do the trick.<ref>[http://www.alllacqueredup.com/2013/06/maybelline-color-show-polka-dots-glitter-nail-polish-swatches-review.html "Maybelline Color Show “Polka Dots” Glitter Nail Polish Swatches & Review"]</ref> *One can create polka-dot brushes for various [[computer graphics]] software, such as [[PhotoShop]], [[GIMP]], etc.<ref>[http://www.graphicxtras.com/polka-dots-brushes-photoshop.htm "Polka dot brushes for Photoshop, PSP, GIMP, Painter ..."]</ref>
