revision.comment: /* top */Typo/[[WP:AWB/GF|general]] fixes, replaced: Scotish → Scottish using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=November 2016}} [[Image:John Logie Baird and Stooky Bill.png|thumb|upright=1.6|Baird in 1925 with his televisor scanner and dummies "James" and "Stooky Bill" ''(right)''. The banks of bright lights were needed to produce a bright enough image at the receiver.]] [[Image:Stooky-Bill.JPG|right|thumb|Modern replica of Stooky Bill.]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Stooky.JPG|right|thumb|Stooky Bill as it would have appeared on Baird's equipment, reproduced using modern [[televisor]] equipment.]] -->
'''Stooky Bill''' was the name given to the head of a [[ventriloquist]] dummy that Scottish television pioneer [[John Logie Baird]] used in his 1924 experiments to transmit a [[television|televised]] image between rooms in his laboratory at 22 Frith Street, London.
Baird invented some of the first experimental [[television]] systems. In 1924 he developed a [[mechanical television]] system to transmit moving images by means of electrical signals, which he demonstrated on 25 March 1925 at a London department store, Selfridges. It consisted of a spinning disk set with a spiral pattern of 30 lenses. As each lens rotated past the illuminated subject, it focused the light from a spot on the subject on a selenium [[photoelectric cell]]. This converted the brightness of the image at each spot into a proportional electric signal, which could be sent to a receiver by radio waves. As each lens swept past the subject, it scanned a successive line of the image. At the receiver, a light shining through the holes in a similar rotating disk recreated an image of the subject.
Due to the low sensitivity of the photoelectric cells, Baird's first system was not able to televise human faces, because they had inadequate contrast. So Baird used a ventriloquist's dummy, whose brightly painted face had greater contrast, and made it move and talk before the scanner. Stooky Bill and another Baird dummy, "James" have been jokingly called "the first television actors".
"Stooky" or "stookie" is [[Scots (language)|Scots]] for [[stucco]] or [[plaster of Paris]], or for a [[Orthopedic cast|plaster cast]] used to immobilise bone fractures.<ref>{{cite book|last=Robinson|first=Mairi|title=The Concise Scots Dictionary|year=1987|publisher=Aberdeen University Press|isbn=0-08-028492-2|pages=673–4}}</ref> The term is also used someone who is slow-witted or awkward in his movements. The [[incandescent light bulb|incandescent lights]] illuminating the subject to be televised generated so much heat that Baird couldn't use a human for the testing, so Stooky Bill was used. Eventually the hair became singed and the painted face became cracked by the heat.
==See also== *[[Mechanical television]] *[[History of television]] *[[Phonovision]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.luxonline.org.uk/artists/david_hall/stooky_bill_tv.html David Hall's video art piece ''Stooky Bill TV'', for Channel 4 TV 1990] *[http://www.nationalmediamuseum.org.uk/collection/television/studioequipment/collectionitem.aspx?id=2001-5037/3 John Logie Baird's test subject 'Stookie Bill' in the collection of the National Media Museum, UK]
[[Category:History of television]] [[Category:Ventriloquists' dummies]]

{{Infobox film | name = Κάλπικη λίρα
(Istoria mias kalpikis liras)
The Counterfeit Coin | director = [[Yorgos Javellas]] | producer = | writer = Yorgos Javellas | narrator = Dimitris Myrat | starring = [[Vassilis Logothetidis]]
Ilia Livykou
[[Mimis Fotopoulos]]
Sperantza Vrana
[[Orestis Makris]]
Maria Kalamioti
[[Ellie Lambeti]]
[[Dimitris Horn]] | music = [[Manos Hatzidakis]] | cinematography = Kostas Theodoridis
Giorgos Tsaoulis | editing = Giorgos Tsaoulis | studio = Anzervos Productions | distributor = Atlantic Films | released = December 28, [[1955 in film|1955]] | runtime = 127 minutes | country = Greece | language = Greek | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Κάλπικη λίρα (Istoria mias kalpikis liras)''''' (English: ''The Counterfeit Coin'') is a [[Greece|Greek]] [[comedy-drama]] film, produced in [[1955 in film|1955]], written and directed by [[Giorgos Tzavellas]] and starring [[Dimitris Horn]], [[Ilia Livykou]] and [[Vassilis Logothetidis]].[http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/news/columns_1KathiLev&xml/&aspKath/columns.asp&fdate=14/09/2006 Kathimerini (English edition)], by Michalis Katsigeras (September 14, 1956), "Commentaries", accessed 01-14-2009[http://www.helleniccomserve.com/counterfeit_coin.html The Hellenic Society Prometheas], "Presents the Classic Greek film ''The Counterfeit Coin'' (I Kalpiki Lira), 1955", accessed 01-14-2009[http://www.cinemainfo.gr/cinemaenglish/greekcinema/history/index.html cinemainfo.gr], History of the Greek cinema, accessed 01-14-2009 At the 2006 [[International Thessaloniki Film Festival]], the film was announced as among the 10 all-time best Greek films by the [[Greek Film Critics Association|PHUCC]] (Pan-Hellenic Union of Cinema Critics).[http://www.cinemainfo.gr/cinemaenglish/cinemanews/47thessalonicafilmfestival/3/index.html cinemainfo.gr], by Giannis Frangoulis (translated by Konstantinos Vassilaros), "47th THESSALONICA FILM FESTIVAL - FOG CASING OVER THE WORLD OF CINEMA", accessed 01-14-2009[http://www.filmfestival.gr/2006/index.php?page=newsdetails&ln=en&box=news&id=118 filmfestival.gr], " The ten best best film of the Greek Film Critics Association", accessed 01-14-2009 ==Plot== {{Expand section|date=April 2010}} An honest, reserved goldsmith and engraver, Anargyros Loumbardopoulos ([[Vassilis Logothetidis]]), has routinely invested his money in gold coins, specifically [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Sovereign (British coin)|gold sovereign]]s, bought from a friend of his, a banker. Upon having stored away 100 sovereigns, a man working for the banker suggests that Anargyros starts [[Coin counterfeiting|minting counterfeit sovereigns]], but he adamantly refuses. The banker employee then introduces Anargyros to a divorced attractive lady, Fifi ([[Ilya Livykou]]) that he knows. Anargyros' resistance is soon curbed by Fifi's sexual means, and he spends all his invested 100 sovereigns to buy minting equipment. After much toil the trio produce their first counterfeit coin but Anargyros finds it difficult to deceive people into accepting it a currency because they easily understand it is not a genuine coin. When the sinister employee is arrested, Anargyros fears that the police has discovered their crime and panicked he gets rid of all the counterfeiting equipment and he also abandons Fifi. It is eventually revealed that it was a misunderstanding and the employee was arrested for other reasons. Safe again, Anargyros returns to his honest work and daily routine but trying to get rid of the counterfeit coin he gives it away as charity to a apparently blind beggar. The beggar sees through the deceit but Anargyros flees in a hurry. The beggar ([[Mimis Fotopoulos]]) is in fact a cunning liar with exceptional eyesight who manages to earn the pity of everyone with his fake blindness. But a street prostitute, Maria ([[Sperantza Vrana]]) starts hooking up near the beggar's corner and they find themselves ==Cast== {{Expand section|date=April 2010}} *[[Vassilis Logothetidis]] as Anargyros Loubardopoulos *[[Ilia Livykou]] as Fifi *[[Mimis Fotopoulos]] as the beggar *[[Sperantza Vrana]] as Maria *[[Orestis Makris]] as Vasilis Mavridis *Maria Kalamioti as Fanitsa *[[Ellie Lambeti]] as Aliki *[[Dimitris Horn]] as Pavlos ;Additional cast *[[Lavrentis Dianellos]] as Anastasis *[[Vageli Protopapas|Vagelis Protopapas]] as Dinos *Lela Patrikiou as Mrs. Mavridou *Dimitris Myrat as the narrator *Zoras Tsapelis as Dimitris *Thanos Tzeneralis as George Phil ==Reception== As part of the closing night event at the Antipodes Greek Film Festival 2005 in [[Melbourne, Australia]], they screened what they considered a classic 50’s film, ''The Counterfeit Coin'' in celebration of the film's 50th anniversary.[http://www.greekcity.com.au/content/content.cfm?id=1413 greekcity.com.au], "GreekFilm Festival - September 2005 Melbourne", accessed 01-14-2009 At the festival, it was said of the film that it was, "Considered by many to be the best Greek film ever produced..." and "There is no more complete Greek cinematic creation".[http://www.goc.com.au/filmfestival05/melbourne/index.htm Antipodes Greek Film Festival], accessed 01-14-2009 And after the festival, "The standout favourites of the Film Festival have been ''Brides'' with 3 sell out screenings to date, ''The Counterfeit Coin'', ''Testosterone'' and ''Liza and The Others''.[http://greekfilmfestival.com.au/filmfestival05/email_news/sydneynews230905/230905GFFNEWS_LIVE.HTM greekfilmfestival.com.au], accessed 01-14-2009 == Other information == The movie saw 1000 simultaneous screenings in Russia. It was a box office success with 208,410 tickets only from the first run in Athens, more than any other movie for that season. It has also been honored with several film awards ([[Venice Film Festival|Venice]], [[Moscow International Film Festival|Moscow]]) and nominations. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0122565|Istoria mias kalpikis liras (The Counterfeit Coin)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Counterfeit Coin}} [[Category:Cinema of Greece]] [[Category:Greek films]] [[Category:1955 films]] [[Category:1950s comedy-drama films]] [[Category:Films directed by George Tzavellas]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} A timeline of notable events relating to [[BBC Radio 1]], a British national radio station which began broadcasts in September 1967.
== 1960s == * '''1967''' **30 September – Radio 1 launches at 7{{nbsp}}am with [[Tony Blackburn]]'s ''Daily Disc Delivery'' show. He welcomes listeners to "the exciting new sound of Radio 1" and then plays the station's first track: [[The Move]]'s "[[Flowers in the Rain]]". **1 October – The first [[List of Peel sessions|Peel Session]] takes place, featuring psychedelic rock band [[Tomorrow (band)|Tomorrow]].
* '''1968''' **January – Tony Blackburn stops presenting the breakfast show on Saturdays. Rather than replace Tony, Radio 1 simulcasts the entirety of Radio 2's breakfast show.
*'''1969''' **April – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] begins his first stint at Radio 1. He would have three stints at the station, the final one ending in 1995. **5 October – [[Annie Nightingale]] makes her debut and becomes the station's first female presenter. **[[Dave Lee Travis]] joins.
==1970s== *'''1970''' ** July – [[Kenny Everett]] is sacked after making cheeky remarks about the [[Secretary of State for Transport|Transport Minister]]'s wife following a news item. **[[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] joins, staying until 1975 before returning for four years in 1989.
*'''1971''' **Radio 1 launches its first promotion badges using the slogan "Go Radio 1 Better on 247". **Radio 1 airs its first documentary, ''The Elvis Presley Story,'' narrated by Wink Martindale.
*'''1972''' **April – [[Terry Wogan]] leaves to take over ''[[The Radio 2 Breakfast Show]]''.
* '''1973''' **8 April – [[Kenny Everett]] briefly returns before moving to [[Capital London|Capital Radio]] later in the year. **1 June – [[Tony Blackburn]] presents his final ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Breakfast Show]]'', having fronted the show since the station went on air in 1967. **4 June – [[Noel Edmonds]] takes over as presenter three days later with Tony moving to the mid-morning slot, taking over from [[Jimmy Young (broadcaster)|Jimmy Young]] who moves to Radio 2. One of the new features of Tony's show is ''[[The Golden Hour (radio feature)|The Golden Hour]],'' an hour of records that charted in the same year. **23 July – The first [[Radio 1 Roadshow]] takes place, broadcast from [[Newquay]], Cornwall and hosted by [[Alan Freeman]]. **10 September – ''[[Newsbeat]]'' bulletins air for the first time. [[Richard Skinner (broadcaster)|Richard Skinner]] joins the station as one of the new programme's presenters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/richard_skinner_page.htm|title=Radio Rewind – BBC Radio 1 People – Richard Skinner|publisher=}}</ref>
*'''1974''' **Radio 1 hosts its first "Fun Day". **[[Stuart Henry (DJ)|Stuart Henry]] leaves.
*'''1975''' **6 January – Broadcasting hours are reduced due to budget cuts at the BBC. All evening programming stops on Radio 1 and the station simulcasts Radio 2 every evening from 7pm. Also the weekday afternoon programme, presented by [[David Hamilton (broadcaster)|David Hamilton]], is broadcast on both stations and [[John Peel]]'s show is moved to the drivetime slot. **11 January – [[Alan Freeman]] broadcasts [[Live at the Empire Pool|a live performance]] by [[Pink Floyd]] which featured a performance of ''[[The Dark Side of the Moon]]'' in its entirety. The performance was recorded at [[Wembley Arena|the Empire Pool]] on 16 November 1974. **September – The first edition of ''The Sunday Request Show'' is broadcast, hosted by [[Annie Nightingale]]. The show runs until 1979 before being re-introduced in 1982, running until the spring of 1994. **27 September – [[Paul Gambaccini]], who joined the station the previous year, presents his first American chart countdown programme. **29 September – [[John Peel]]'s show moves back to late evenings. For this, Radio 1 'borrows' Radio 2's VHF/FM frequencies on weeknights again (having previously done so from October 1971 to December 1974, for shows hosted by Peel, Annie Nightingale and Bob Harris among others). This one hour on weeknights is the only time of the evening that Radio 1 broadcasts its own programmes, and Radio 1 now ends weekday transmissions an hour earlier, at 6pm.
*'''1976''' **May – [[Simon Bates]] gets his first regular show. **September – [[Emperor Rosko]] leaves to return to America. **December – The first ''[[Festive Fifty]]'' is revealed by [[John Peel]]. **[[David Jensen]] joins.
*'''1977''' **4 April – Radio 1 extends its weeknight broadcasting hours. The station's daytime weekday programmes are extended by an hour to 7pm and the [[John Peel]] show is also extended by an hour, to two hours. Consequently, Radio 1 now borrows Radio 2's VHF/FM frequencies for two hours each weeknight – between 10pm and midnight. **28 November – From today, Radio 1 has its own all-day weekday schedule with the launch of a new afternoon programme presented by [[Tony Blackburn]]; [[David Hamilton (broadcaster)|David Hamilton]]'s show, simulcast on both stations since January 1975, moves to Radio 2 only. Tony is replaced on mid-mornings by [[Simon Bates]]. Consequently Radio 1 now has its own all-day schedule on weekdays. However the station continues to simulcast Radio 2 each night from 7pm, apart from the weekday late night John Peel programme. **[[Peter Powell (DJ)|Peter Powell]] joins.
*'''1978''' **2 May – [[Dave Lee Travis]] succeeds [[Noel Edmonds]] as presenter of the ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Breakfast Show]]'' and [[David Jensen]] takes over the drivetime slot that Dave vacates. **12 November – The Sunday teatime chart show is extended from a Top 20 countdown to a Top 40 countdown. [[Simon Bates]] is the presenter, having taken over as host from [[Tom Browne (broadcaster)|Tom Browne]] earlier in the year. **17 November – [[Tommy Vance]], one of the station's original presenters, rejoins Radio 1 to present a new programme, ''[[The Friday Rock Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1978-11-17|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 17 November 1978 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> Consequently, [[John Peel]] is now on air four nights a week instead of five. **23 November – Radio 1 moves from 247m (1214 kHz) to 275 & 285m (1053 & 1089 kHz) medium wave as part of a plan to improve national AM reception, and to conform with the [[Geneva Frequency Plan of 1975]].<ref name="radiorewind1">{{cite web|url= http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/transmitter.htm|title= Radio 1 History – Transmitters|publisher= Radio Rewind|accessdate= 18 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frequencyfinder.org.uk/History_Transmission.pdf|title = History of Radio Transmission in the UK|publisher= Frequency Finder}}</ref>
*'''1979''' **29 January – Radio 1 begins its delayed weeknight mid-evening programme with [[Andy Peebles]] joining to host the new programme. It had originally been scheduled to launch on 13 November 1978 but was delayed as a result of [[Winter of Discontent|trade union disputes]].
==1980s==
*'''1980''' **5 January – [[Tony Blackburn]] replaces [[Ed Stewart]] as host of ''[[Junior Choice]]'', and [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]] joins to present the Saturday evening show. **31 March – Radio 1's broadcast hours are cut back. The station starts broadcasting on weekdays an hour later and Saturday evening programming ends. The station simulcasts Radio 2 during this additional downtime although by the end of the year Radio 1 has stopped broadcasting Radio 2 through the night. **6 December – [[Andy Peebles]] interviews [[John Lennon]] and [[Yoko Ono]] in [[New York City]], just two days before Lennon was assassinated.
*'''1981''' **5 January – [[Mike Read]] succeeds [[Dave Lee Travis]] as presenter of the ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Breakfast Show]]''. **September – [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]], who joined the station the previous year, takes over the weekday afternoon slot, thereby launching ''[[Steve Wright in the Afternoon]]''. His new show brings the [[zoo format]] to the UK.
*'''1982''' **10 January – [[Tommy Vance]] replaces [[Tony Blackburn]] as host of Radio 1's ''Top 40'' show. **6 March – ''[[Junior Choice]]'' leaves the airwaves and the weekend breakfast show is renamed ''The Saturday Show/The Sunday Show''. Children's requests continue to be a mainstay of the renamed show and [[Maggie Philbin]] and [[Keith Chegwin]] join Tony Blackburn as co-presenters. **4 December – The transmission time lost in March 1980 is regained. Programmes once again begin at 6{{nbsp}}am, finally ending all simulcasts between Radio 1 and Radio 2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1982-12-06|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 6 December 1982 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> [[Mike Smith (broadcaster)|Mike Smith]] returns to the station – he had been a presenter and producer in the mid 1970s – to present the new weekday early show. Weekend early shows are introduced with [[Adrian John]] and [[Pat Sharp]] joining to host the new programmes. The station also recommences Saturday evening broadcasting with [[Janice Long]] and [[Gary Davies]] joining to present the new shows. Programming is also extended by two hours on Sunday evenings with [[Annie Nightingale]]'s request show returning to the airwaves after a three-year hiatus. Thus Radio 1 is now on air daily from 6{{nbsp}}am until midnight.
*'''1983''' **28 February – [[Adrian John]] takes over the weekday early show from [[Mike Smith (broadcaster)|Mike Smith]] who moves to the lunchtime show. **1 October – [[Mark Page]] joins to present the weekend early show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1983-10-01|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 1 October 1983 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> [[Pat Sharp]] leaves. **18 December – ''[[Sounds of Jazz]]'' is broadcast on Radio 1 for the final time. From the new year the show is broadcast on Radio 2.
*'''1984''' **8 January – [[Simon Bates]] returns to the Sunday teatime Top 40 programme, but only for a few months as [[Richard Skinner (broadcaster)|Richard Skinner]] takes over as host on 30 September. **26 March – [[Gary Davies]] replaces [[Mike Smith (broadcaster)|Mike Smith]] as host of the weekday lunchtime programme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1984-03-26|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 26 March 1984 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **[[David Jensen]] leaves and is replaced on the mid-evening show by [[Janice Long]]. **10 September – [[Bruno Brookes]] replaces [[Peter Powell (DJ)|Peter Powell]] as presenter of the teatime show. **23 September – [[Tony Blackburn]], the first voice heard on Radio 1, presents his final show for the station.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1984-09-23|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 23 September 1984 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> The following weekend, Peter Powell replaces Tony as presenter of the weekend breakfast show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1984-09-29|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 29 September 1984 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''1985''' **31 March – [[Ranking Miss P]] becomes the station's first black female DJ when she begins presenting the station's first reggae programme. This was not her first appearance on the station, however, as she had been sitting in for other presenters for the past year. **6 July – [[Andy Kershaw]] joins.<ref name="Cook">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/john-peel-and-andy-kershaw--how-we-met-1572794.html|title=John Peel and Andy Kershaw: How We Met|first=Emma|last=Cook|work=[[The Independent]]|date=12 February 1995|location=London, UK|issn=0951-9467|oclc=185201487|accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref> **13 July – Radio 1 broadcasts full, live coverage of the [[Live Aid]] pop concerts. **[[Johnny Beerling]] replaces [[Derek Chinnery]] as station controller.
*'''1986''' ** February – [[Paul Gambaccini]] presents his final programme for Radio 1, leaving after presenting the station's American chart programme for the previous decade. **13 April – [[Bruno Brookes]] takes over as the host of the [[UK Singles Chart]]. **18 April – [[Mike Read]] presents his final ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' after five years in the hot seat. **5 May – [[Mike Smith (broadcaster)|Mike Smith]] rejoins Radio 1, after spending the past two years working for BBC television, to take over the breakfast show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1986-05-05|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 5 May 1986 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> The same day also sees Radio 1 begin broadcasting on weekdays 30 minutes earlier, at 5:30{{nbsp}}am. **[[Simon Mayo]] joins.
*'''1987''' **17 January – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] returns to Radio 1 to present a new Saturday afternoon programme ''The Stereo Sequence''.<ref>[http://aircheckdownloads.com/Radio1_JohnnieWalker_17Jan87.mp3 Audio of Johnnie Walker's return to Radio 1]</ref> The programme, which runs for 5 1/2 hours, incorporates the previous stand-alone Saturday afternoon shows, including the weekly look at the American charts, which is shortened to an hour. **4 October – From this day, the new [[UK Singles Chart]] is released on the Sunday afternoon chart show. Previously, the programme had played songs from the chart which had been released the previous Tuesday. **31 October – Radio 1 begins launching its [[FM radio|FM]] frequency, starting in London, initially on 104.8 MHz before moving to the 97–99 frequency range allocated to the station.<ref name="radiorewind1"/> **[[Nicky Campbell]] and [[Mark Goodier]] join and [[Janice Long]] leaves.
*'''1988''' **January – The station has a "More Music Day" which limited presenter chat to news, weather and travel. It was designed as an answer to those who thought that DJs talk too much. It has not been repeated. **May – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] ends his second stint at the station and [[Roger Scott]] takes over as host of ''The Stereo Sequence''. **23 May – [[Simon Mayo]] takes over from [[Mike Smith (broadcaster)|Mike Smith]] as presenter of the ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Breakfast Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/d8f0c965e8064233bad88a190ebf1138|title=Simon Mayo – BBC Radio 1 England – 23 May 1988 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aircheckdownloads.com/Radio1_SimonMayo_23May88.mp3|title=Audio of Simon Mayo’s first breakfast show|publisher=|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **1 September – ***The Radio 1 FM 'switch on' day which sees three new transmitters brought into service covering central Scotland, the north of England and the Midlands. With 65% of the UK now covered by the station's new FM frequency, the pop group [[Bros]] fly around the country in a helicopter to encourage listeners to switch over.<ref name="radiorewind1"/> ***To co-inside with the switch-ons, ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' is simulcast on the station for the first time giving listeners the chance to hear the programme in stereo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1988-09-01|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 1 September 1988 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **25 September – [[Peter Powell (DJ)|Peter Powell]] leaves<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aircheckdownloads.com/Radio1_PeterPowell_25Sept88.mp3|title=Audio of the last part of Peter Powell’s last show for Radio 1|publisher=|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> and the following weekend [[Liz Kershaw]] and [[Mark Goodier]] launch an extended weekend breakfast show, which starts at the earlier time of 6{{nbsp}}am, subsuming the early show which for the past year had been presented by [[Nicky Campbell]]. ***[[Jackie Brambles]] joins. **29 September – ***Radio 1 'borrows' [[BBC Radio 2]]'s FM frequencies on a weeknight for the final time. *** Radio 1 starts broadcasting on FM in South Wales and the west of England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1988-09-29|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 29 September 1988 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **1 October – ***Radio 1 extends broadcasting hours, closing down at 2{{nbsp}}am instead of midnight. This results in a new weekday evening schedule with [[John Peel]] moving to an earlier evening slot, Nicky Campbell taking over the late show and [[Richard Skinner (broadcaster)|Richard Skinner]] rejoining after two years at [[Capital London|Capital]] to host the new midnight to 2{{nbsp}}am show. ***''The Stereo Sequence'' is renamed ''The Saturday Sequence''. **25 November – Radio 1 starts broadcasting on FM in [[Belfast]] and [[Oxfordshire]]. To mark the event, the breakfast show and [[Simon Bates]] programmes are broadcast live from the two areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1988-11-25|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 25 November 1988 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''1989''' **15 January – [[Alan Freeman]] rejoins to revive ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'' and ''The Rock Show''. **1 April – Radio 1 starts broadcasting slightly earlier each morning and is now on air between 5{{nbsp}}am and 2{{nbsp}}am seven days a week. [[Tim Smith (DJ)|Tim Smith]] joins to host the new weekend early breakfast show. **3 July – [[Simon Bates]] and producer Jonathan Ruffle set off on an 80-day circumnavigation of the world to raise money for [[Oxfam]]. Their progress is charted in a broadcast each weekday morning.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/09/50-historic-moments-for-bbc-radio-1s-50th/|title=50 historic moments for BBC Radio 1’s 50th – RadioToday|website=radiotoday.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **29 September – [[Adrian John]] leaves after presenting the weekday early show for the past six years. He is replaced by [[Jackie Brambles]]. **31 October – [[Roger Scott]] dies aged 46, three weeks after presenting his final show. [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] rejoins Radio 1 as Roger's Sunday late show replacement. **19 December – Radio 1 starts transmitting on FM across the whole of south-east England (replacing the temporary London transmitter), in East Anglia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1989-12-19 |work=BBC Genome Project |title=BBC Radio 1 listings 19 December 1989 |accessdate=22 July 2017}}</ref> and in the [[Cardigan Bay]] area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aircheckdownloads.com/Radio1_AndyPeebles_19Dec89.mp3|title=Audio of the switch-on of the Cardigan Bay transmitter|publisher=|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **30 December – Radio 1 broadcasts on Radio 2's FM frequencies on Saturday afternoons for the final time.
==1990s== *'''1990''' **8 January – ***A new 30 minute news programme ''News 90'' replaces the teatime edition of [[Newsbeat]]. ***A new jingles package called "Music Radio for the 90s" is launched. **11 February – Radio 1 starts broadcasting on FM in most of south west England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1990-02-11|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 11 February 1990 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **17 March – [[Gary King (radio)|Gary King]] joins to take over the early breakfast show, initially replacing [[Tim Smith (DJ)|Tim Smith]] at the weekend before moving to the weekday early show to replace [[Jackie Brambles]], who moves to the weekday teatime show. **25 March – Radio 1 'borrows' [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]]'s FM frequencies for the final time. **12 April – Radio 1 starts broadcasting on FM throughout north east England (having previously had a low-power transmitter for [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] for a period); as this area is a renowned heartland of heavy rock music, [[Tommy Vance]] hosts a special ''[[Friday Rock Show]]'' live from Newcastle to mark the occasion.<ref>[http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/efb9d7bbcf334ddd9852d0b23976e9d1 BBC Genome listing for the 13 April 1990 Friday Rock Show]</ref> **24 May – Radio 1 begins FM transmission in central southern England with a Steve Wright outside broadcast from [[Goodwood Racecourse]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1990-05-24|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 24 May 1990 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> Also during 1990, the transmitters established in 1988 move to higher power. **30 September – [[Mark Goodier]] replaces [[Bruno Brookes]] as host of Radio 1's Top 40 show. **1 October – A shake-up of the station's evening schedules sees the debut of a "new music" show ''[[The Evening Session]]''. Consequently, John Peel's show is moved to the weekend.
*'''1991''' **6 January – For the first time, Radio 1's Sunday chart show plays all 40 tracks and the show is renamed as ''The Complete Top 40''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1991-01-06|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 6 January 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> This becomes possible due to an extension of the programme's duration – starting half an hour earlier at 4:30{{nbsp}}pm. **11 January – ''[[Essential Selection|The Essential Selection]]'', presented by [[Pete Tong]], debuts. It replaces ''[[Jeff Young’s Big Beat]]'', which had launched in 1987 as Radio 1's first dance music programme. **1 May – Radio 1 commences 24-hour transmission, but only on FM – the station's MW frequencies are switched off each night between midnight and 6{{nbsp}}am. [[Lynn Parsons]] joins to present one of the new overnight shows. **5–30 August – [[Phil Collins]], [[The Pet Shop Boys]], [[Jason Donovan]] and [[Whitney Houston]] are ''Bates's Mates'', who deputised for [[Simon Bates]] on Radio 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1991-08-05|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 5 August 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **29 August – ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' is simulcast on Radio 1 for the last time, the programme introduced by [[Jackie Brambles]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/95f82c7c1dc746f8b7116d629550946f |title=Top of the Pops – BBC Radio 1 England – 29 August 1991 – BBC Genome |publisher=Genome.ch.bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=13 January 2018}}</ref> **28 September – [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] returns to Radio 1 for the third time, returning to begin his second stint as the station's Saturday afternoon presenter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1991-09-28|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 28 September 1991 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> He replaces the departing [[Richard Skinner (broadcaster)|Richard Skinner]]. Johnnie's return comes one day after [[Mike Read]]'s departure from the station.
*'''1992''' **21 February – [[Gary Davies]] presents his final 'bit in the middle.' [[Jackie Brambles]] replaces Davies as host of the weekday lunchtime show on 24 February. **9 March – Radio 1 undergoes a schedule revamp, with most of the changes being to the weekend schedule, including [[Gary Davies]] becoming host of the weekend breakfast show. [[Gary King (radio)|Gary King]]<ref>[http://aircheckdownloads.com/Radio1_GaryKing_06Mar92.mp3 Audio of Gary King’s final hosting of the Radio 1 early breakfast show]</ref> and [[Andy Peebles]] leave. The changes also see the introduction of a new jingles package, based on the theme ''Closer to the Music''. **15 March – ***[[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] makes his Radio 1 debut, presenting a short-lived Sunday early afternoon show called ''Too Much Gravy''. He leaves in September to take over as co-presenter of [[Channel 4]]'s new breakfast show ''[[The Big Breakfast]]. ***[[Bruno Brookes]] returns as host of the UK Top 40 programme. The programme is extended once again and now airs from 4{{nbsp}}pm until 7{{nbsp}}pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1992-03-15|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 15 March 1992 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **20 April – ''[[The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert|The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert for AIDS Awareness]]'', an open-air concert in tribute to the late [[Freddie Mercury]] is held at [[London]]'s [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]]. The concert is broadcast on [[BBC Two|BBC2]] and [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] in the UK, and televised worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/3de1ffa36fb646aaa8155c0d9c0ee33c |title=The Freddie Mercury Tribute – BBC Two England – 20 April 1992 |work=BBC Genome |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/6af87519ef624c5592691fa626949ed7|title=The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert – BBC Radio 1 England – 20 April 1992 |work=BBC Genome|publisher=BBC|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **30 August – 100,000 people attend [[BBC Radio 1]]'s biggest ever [[Radio 1 Roadshow|Roadshow]] to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Radio 1. The event, held at [[Sutton Park]] in the West Midlands, features live performances from bands including [[Del Amitri]], [[Aswad (band)|Aswad]], [[The Farm (British band)|The Farm]] and [[Status Quo (band)|Status Quo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1992-08-30|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 30 August 1992 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=21 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/roadshow_later.htm|title=Radio Rewind – Radio 1 Shows – Roadshow; the later years|website=www.radiorewind.co.uk|accessdate=21 October 2018}}</ref> **27 December – ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'' is broadcast on Radio 1 for the final time.
*'''1993''' **March – After nearly 15 years of presenting ''[[The Friday Rock Show]]'', [[Tommy Vance]] leaves to go to new station [[Absolute Radio|Virgin 1215]]. **18 April – ''The Official 1 FM Album Chart'' show is broadcast for the first time. Presented by [[Lynn Parsons]], the 60-minute programme is broadcast on Sunday evenings, straight after the Top 40 singles chart. **8 August – [[Dave Lee Travis]] resigns on air, stating that he could not agree with changes that were being made to Radio 1. Travis told his audience that changes were afoot that he could not tolerate "and I really want to put the record straight at this point and I thought you ought to know – changes are being made here which go against my principles and I just cannot agree with them".<ref>{{cite web | title=Profile: Dave Lee Travis | work=Aircheck Tracker | url=http://www.geocities.com/thehotw/DLTtracker.htm | accessdate = 13 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022161312/http://geocities.com/thehotw/DLTtracker.htm|archivedate=22 October 2009}}</ref> **16 August – 20 September – ''[[Loud'n'proud]]'', a series presented by [[DJ Paulette]], is the UK's first national radio series aimed at a [[gay]] audience. **3 September – [[Simon Mayo]] leaves the ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' after five years in the chair. Simon moves to mid-mornings. [[Mark Goodier]] takes over as presenter until the end of the year. ** September – [[Steve Lamacq]] and [[Jo Whiley]] replace [[Mark Goodier]] as host of ''[[The Evening Session]]''. ** October – Major changes to the output take place following [[Matthew Bannister]] replacing [[Johnny Beerling]] as controller. The changes, which are designed to reposition the station to attract a younger audience, see long standing DJs, including [[Simon Bates]], [[Gary Davies]], [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] and [[Alan Freeman]], leave in the months surrounding the changes. They are replaced with a raft of new younger presenters, and specialist music programmes, previously heard late at night, are given weekend afternoon slots. ** 30 October – As part of the roll-out of the new schedule, [[Andy Kershaw]] and [[John Peel]] move from nighttime to Saturday afternoons and [[Danny Baker]] takes over the weekend morning show. Also, this day sees the first broadcast of ''[[Essential Mix]]''. **24 December – ''[[Steve Wright in the Afternoon]]'' ends its 13-year run on Radio 1.
*'''1994''' **1 January – [[Kevin Greening]] joins the station and takes over Weekend Breakfast from the recently departed [[Gary Davies]]. **10 January – ***[[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]] becomes Radio 1's latest breakfast show presenter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1994-01-10|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 10 January 1994 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> Other changes on this day see [[Mark Goodier]] present a new early afternoon show with [[Nicky Campbell]] hosting the drive time show and [[Emma Freud]] as the host of the lunchtime show to replace [[Jackie Brambles]] who leaves for America. ***The teatime edition of ''[[Newsbeat]]'' returns after four years. The bulletin airs in its old slot – 5:30{{nbsp}}pm to 5:45{{nbsp}}pm. **1 May - [[Annie Nightingale]] hosts the request show for the final time, having presented the programme since 1982. [[Lynn Parsons]] takes over as the show's presenter the following week, but it is dropped entirely six months later. **8 May – ***In the early hours of Sunday 8 May, [[Annie Nightingale]] launches her career as a club music DJ, presenting the first edition of ''The Chill Out Zone''. ***After six months of rocking Sunday afternoons, the rock show moves to mid-evenings, swapping slots with ''The Steve Edwards Soul Show''. **June – Radio 1 begins broadcasting announcements on its medium wave frequency voiced by [[Nicky Campbell]] telling listeners to retune to FM because it will no longer be broadcasting on medium wave from 1 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/transmitter.htm|title=Radio Rewind – Radio 1 History – Transmitters|website=www.radiorewind.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **1 July – Radio 1's last broadcast on [[mediumwave]]. [[Stephen Duffy]]'s "Kiss Me" was the last record played on MW just before 9:00am.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/transmitter.htm|title= Radio 1 History – Transmitters|publisher= Radio Rewind|accessdate= 30 December 2009}}</ref> **19 September – [[Danny Rampling]] joins.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1994-11-19|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 19 November 1994 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **Radio 1 starts broadcasting on satellite, using audio carriers on the [[Astra (satellite)|Astra satellite]]. ** 27 November – [[Clive Warren]] joins from [[Capital Radio]] and takes over Weekend Breakfast from [[Kevin Greening]] who moves to Weekend Lunchtime. ** 10 December – [[Tim Westwood]] joins to present the station's first long-standing rap show, although [[Pete Tong]] has hosted ''The Rap Selection'' in 1991 and 1992, a continuation of the ''National Fresh'' segment in Jeff Young's Friday night show in the late 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1994-12-10|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 10 December 1994 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''1995''' **Radio 1's roll-out of its FM network is completed and the station now has the same coverage on FM as the other BBC national stations. **21 April – [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]]<ref>[https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1995-04-21 BBC Genome project Radio 1 listings 21 April 1995]</ref> and [[Bruno Brookes]] present their final shows for the station. **23 April – Following [[Bruno Brookes]]'s departure, [[Mark Goodier]] begins his second stint as presenter of the Sunday afternoon Top 40 show. **24 April – [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] takes over the ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' from [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]], who left the network following differences with the station's new management over restructuring and [[Dave Pearce]] joins to take over the early breakfast show. **July – The station holds its first [[Ibiza]] weekend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/timelines/zx4mhv4|title=Radio 1 in Ibiza: 20 years of raving on the White Isle|website=BBC Timelines|accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref> **27 September – The [[BBC]] begins regular [[Digital Audio Broadcasting]], from the [[Crystal Palace transmitting station]]. **21 October – Ahead of a schedule revamp, [[Johnnie Walker (DJ)|Johnnie Walker]] leaves Radio 1 for the last time. The changes include [[Clive Warren]] moving from the weekend breakfast show to the weekday early show, replacing [[Dave Pearce]] who launches a new weekend mid-morning show, replacing [[Kevin Greening]] who takes over weekend breakfasts, which includes a new weekend breakfast Newsbeat presented by [[Peter Bowes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1995-10-21|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 21 October 1995 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''1996''' **4 February – [[Trevor Nelson]] joins to present the UK's first national r&b show ''Rhythm Nation''. **June – Radio 1 starts live streaming on the internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.bbc.co.uk/support/history.html|title=BBC Internet Services – History|publisher=BBC|accessdate=26 January 2009}}</ref> **[[Lynn Parsons]] leaves.
*'''1997''' **January – [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] leaves the ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show|Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' after being sacked for demanding a four day week, sparing Fridays to work on his [[Channel 4]] TV show. **17 February – ***[[Mark and Lard]] become the Radio 1 breakfast show's new presenters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/e5f4650da7db45d49cda1f8237923a95|title=Mark Radcliffe – BBC Radio 1 England – 17 February 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> ***[[Jo Whiley]] begins presenting a weekday lunchtime show on Radio 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/afa424b163a44195ac311beea4708982|title=Jo Whiley – BBC Radio 1 England – 17 February 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> **27 July – The first edition of ''[[Radio 1's Dance Anthems]]'' is broadcast, hosted by [[Dave Pearce]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1997-07-27|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 27 July 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **28 July – [[Chris Moyles]] becomes the new host of the Early Breakfast Show.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/892ed7bf6b2d43a2ac406739709cd198|title=Chris Moyles – BBC Radio 1 England – 28 July 1997 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> **31 August – Regular programming is interrupted on all BBC stations to provide ongoing news coverage of the [[death of Diana, Princess of Wales]]. Radio 1 cancels all programmes, including the Top 40 programme, and replaces them with non-stop music and extended news bulletins every 30 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kwF1fpwxmg8|title=Reporting of the Death of Diana, Princess of Wales|first=|last=RandomRadioJottings|date=28 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=14 July 2018|via=YouTube}}</ref> **13 October – Mark and Lard are replaced as Radio 1 breakfast presenters by [[Zoë Ball]] and [[Kevin Greening]]. Mark and Lard are moved to an afternoon slot. **October – [[Nicky Campbell]] leaves to join [[BBC Radio 5 Live]].
*'''1998''' **March – [[Andy Parfitt]] replaces [[Matthew Bannister]] as station controller. **25 September – [[Kevin Greening]] leaves the weekday breakfast show, leaving [[Zoë Ball]] as sole presenter. He replaces [[Clive Warren]] as host of the Sunday breakfast show. **12 October – [[Chris Moyles]] is promoted from the Early Breakfast show to present the Radio 1 Early Drive show, between 4{{nbsp}}pm and 5:45{{nbsp}}pm on weekdays (later being extended to 3{{nbsp}}pm{{snd}}5:45{{nbsp}}pm). He replaces [[Dave Pearce]], who moves to a new early evening show. Moyles is replaced on Early Breakfast by [[Scott Mills]].
*'''1999''' **19 September – The first edition of a new Sunday evening advice programme called ''[[The Surgery|The Sunday Surgery]]'' is broadcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/radio1/england/1999-09-19|title=BBC Radio 1 England – 19 September 1999 – BBC Genome|website=genome.ch.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **Radio 1 broadcasts its first split programming when it introduces weekly national new music shows for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. **Radio 1's Live Lounge is established as part of the mid-morning show. The programmes are broadcast on a three-weekly rotational basis in England. **[[Sara Cox]] joins
==2000s== *'''2000''' **16 January – [[Kevin Greening]] leaves. The following week a new Sunday breakfast show, ''The Breakfast Club'', hosted by Sarah HB, launches. **31 March – [[Sara Cox]] replaces [[Zoë Ball]] as presenter of the ''[[Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]''. **May – [[Andy Kershaw]] leaves. He had presented the station's world music programme since 1987.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2000/may/28/bbc.uknews|title=BBC under fire for teen bias after DJ is axed|first=Vanessa|last=Thorpe|date=28 May 2000|website=the Guardian|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> **September – [[Clive Warren]] leaves.
*'''2001''' **19 February – [[Jo Whiley]] begins presenting her weekday morning programme, ''[[The Jo Whiley Show]]'', replacing [[Simon Mayo]] who leaves the station to join [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] and [[BBC Radio 2]]. **10 May – Radio 1 loses its crown as the UK's most listened to radio station to [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/may/10/broadcasting.bbc|title=Radio 2 is top UK station|date=10 May 2001|website=the Guardian|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''2002''' **March – [[Danny Rampling]] leaves. **16 August – Spin-off station [[BBC Radio 1Xtra]] launches. **17 November – [[Mark Goodier]] presents the Top 40 for the final time on the 50th anniversary of the chart.before leaving the station entirely in 2002 owing to falling audiences and BBC bosses considering him "too old for the job."<ref name="bbc1">"… Radio 1 denied he has been fired because of falling listener figures, saying his contract is coming to an end."{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/2195178.stm|title=DJ Goodier leaves Radio 1 |date=15 August 2002 |work=Entertainment News |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=18 May 2009}}</ref><ref name="graun1">"… station bosses want to replace him with someone younger, who will be more in tune with its target audience of 15 to 24-year-olds." {{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/aug/15/broadcasting.bbc2 |title=Countdown begins for Goodier's departure |last=Day |first=Julia |date=15 August 2002 |work=Media Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |accessdate=18 May 2009}}</ref><ref name="indie1">"Mark Goodier is leaving Radio 1's weekly chart show after 15 years because he is considered too old for the job." {{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/goodier-drops-out-of-the-charts-640021.html |title=Goodier drops out of the charts |last=Gray |first=Chris |date=16 August 2002 |work=The Independent |accessdate=18 May 2009}}</ref>
*'''2003''' **9 February – [[Wes Butters]] becomes the presenter of ''[[The Official Chart]]''. **3 May – Radio 1 cancels the first day of its [[One Big Weekend]] at [[Heaton Park]], [[Manchester]] due to poor weather. However, the second day of the event goes ahead as scheduled.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio1/onebigweekend/2003/manchester/press_release.shtml |title=Radio 1 – One Big Weekend |publisher=BBC |date=3 May 2003 |accessdate=24 March 2012}}</ref> **13 and 14 September – Radio 1's second [[One Big Weekend]] festival takes place at [[Cardiff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/08_august/29/big_weekend_cardiff.shtml |title=Press Office – One Big Weekend Cardiff |publisher=BBC |date=24 September 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref> **19 December – [[Sara Cox]] presents her final breakfast show. ** [[Zane Lowe]] joins to present a new weeknight evening show.
*'''2004''' **5 January – [[Chris Moyles]] takes over the ''[[The Chris Moyles Show|breakfast show]].'' **26 March – [[Mark and Lard]] ([[Mark Radcliffe (radio broadcaster)|Mark Radcliffe]] and [[Marc Riley]]) present their final show, after 11 years and one failed eight-month stint on [[the Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]. **7 June – [[Scott Mills]] takes over as presenter of the ''[[The Scott Mills Show|drivetime show]]''.
*'''2005''' **6 March – [[JK and Joel]] take over as presenters of ''[[The Official Chart]]''. **13 October – Radio 1 hosts the first [[John Peel|John Peel Day]], a year after John presented his final show for the station which was two weeks before his death.
*'''2006''' **8 March – Radio 1 launches its [[YouTube]] channel.
*'''2007''' **1 June – [[Greg James (DJ)|Greg James]] joins. **14 October – [[Fearne Cotton]] and [[Reggie Yates]] take over as presenters of ''[[The Official Chart]]''. **18 December – Radio 1 is forced to backtrack on a decision to begin playing a censored version of [[The Pogues]]' 1987 Christmas hit ''[[Fairytale of New York]]''. The song which sees [[Kirsty MacColl]] and [[Shane MacGowan]] trading insults has the words "[[faggot (epithet)|faggot]]" and "[[slut]]" edited out to "avoid offence", but after a day of criticism from listeners, the band, and MacColl's mother, the decision is reversed and the original version played in full.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|date=18 December 2007|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/12/18/npogues118.xml|title= BBC censors The Pogues' Christmas classic|accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref><ref name="bbc-backs-down">{{cite news|work=BBC News|date=18 December 2007|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7150693.stm|title= Radio 1 backs down in Pogues row]|publisher= BBC|accessdate= 16 December 2012}}</ref> **[[BBC Introducing]] is launched, providing a vital platform for thousands of emerging musical talent. A decade later over 460,000 tracks have been uploaded to the BBC Music Introducing website and 170,000 artists are registered.
*'''2008''' **August – [[Dave Pearce]] leaves.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/organgrinder/2008/aug/14/farewellbbcradio1djdavep|title=Farewell BBC Radio 1 DJ Dave Pearce|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=14 August 2008|website=the Guardian|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
*'''2009''' **18 September – [[Jo Whiley]] presents her final ''[[The Jo Whiley Show|weekday programme]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5glJr4020gJ-2sWdqGptl0DfI5Mcg|title= Whiley bows out with full house|publisher= Press Association|date= 18 September 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> **21 September – [[Fearne Cotton]] takes over the mid-morning show and stops presenting ''[[The Official Chart]]'', leaving [[Reggie Yates]] as the programme's sole presenter.
==2010s== *'''2010''' **31 May – Radio 1 teams up with forces broadcaster [[British Forces Broadcasting Service|BFBS]] for a ten-hour takeover show from [[Camp Bastion]], Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/media/news/a219937/radio-1-bfbs-partner-for-afghanistan-day.html|title= Radio 1, BFBS partner for Afghanistan day|publisher= |work= Digital Spy|first= Andrew|last= Laughlin|date= 14 May 2010|accessdate= 8 April 2012}}</ref>
*'''2011''' **18 March – [[Chris Moyles]] breaks the record for presenting the longest radio programme, after hosting a 52-hour live broadcast in aid of [[BBC Radio 1's Longest Show Ever with Chris Moyles and Comedy Dave for Comic Relief|Comic Relief 2011]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/12782536|title=Chris Moyles breaks radio show record for Comic Relief|publisher=BBC|work=BBC Radio 1 NewsBeat|date=18 March 2011|accessdate=20 March 2011}}</ref> **April – [[Jo Whiley]] leaves Radio 1 after 17 years to move to [[BBC Radio 2]], where she will present an evening show from Mondays to Wednesdays.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12333440|title= Jo Whiley to switch to Radio 2|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|date= 1 February 2011|accessdate= 16 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110203050159/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12333440| archivedate= 3 February 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> **21 July – The BBC confirms that [[Andy Parfitt]] will step down as Controller of Radio 1 after 13 years to pursue other opportunities from the end of the month.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/07_july/21/parfitt.shtml |title=Andy Parfitt leaves Radio 1 after 13 years as Controller |publisher=BBC |work= BBC Press Office |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=4 March 2012}}</ref> **28 October – [[Ben Cooper (media executive)|Ben Cooper]] is appointed as Controller of Radio 1 and [[BBC 1Xtra|1Xtra]], replacing [[Andy Parfitt]] who stepped down in July.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/10_october/28/radio1.shtml|title= Ben Cooper appointed Controller, BBC Radio 1 & 1Xtra|publisher= BBC|work= BBC Press Office|date= 28 October 2011|accessdate= 1 March 2012}}</ref>
*'''2012''' **26 February – The Top Ten countdown from ''[[The Radio 1 Chart Show]]'' is made available in vision for the first time through the station's website.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/01/radio-1-chart-goes-visual-for-last-hour/ |title=Radio 1 chart goes visual for last hour |publisher=Radio Today |date=22 January 2012 |accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> **2 April – A shake-up of the schedule sees [[Scott Mills]] and [[Greg James (DJ)|Greg James]] swapping shows, James hosting the drivetime show and Mills the afternoon show.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/02/greg-james-to-host-bbc-radio-1-drivetime/ |title=Greg James to host BBC Radio 1 Drivetime |publisher=Radio Today |date=28 February 2012 |accessdate=1 March 2012}}</ref> Also major changes take place to the dance music schedule: [[Skream]] & [[Benga (musician)|Benga]], [[Toddla T]], [[Charlie Sloth]] and Friction will take over from [[Judge Jules]], [[Gilles Peterson]], [[Kissy Sell Out]] and [[Fabio (DJ)|Fabio]] & [[Grooverider]] resulting in a shuffle of most late night shows Monday to Saturday to incorporate the new line-up.<ref>{{cite news|first=Ben |last=Cooper |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/071211radio1.html |title=Media Centre – Radio 1 announces changes to dance music line-up |publisher=BBC |work= BBC Press Office |date=7 December 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref> **June – The regional new music shows are scrapped after thirteen years as a cost cutting measure<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-18083178 |title=Children's shows to leave BBC One |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> and replaced by [[BBC Introducing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01jk7zb |title=BBC Radio 1 – BBC Introducing with Jen and Ally |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref> **20 June – The [[BBC Trust]] says that Radio 1′s core audience is still too old, despite changes made to output following an amendment to the wording of its service licence in 2009. The station is aimed at the 15–29-year age group, but the average age of their listeners is 30.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/06/bbc-trust-radio-1-fails-to-meet-targets/ |title=BBC Trust: Radio 1 fails to meet targets |publisher=Radio Today |date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref> **23–24 June – 100,000 people attend Radio 1's [[Hackney Weekend]], a two-day music concert at [[Hackney Marshes]], which forms part of the build-up to the [[2012 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Kitty |last=Empire |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/jun/23/radio-1-hackney-weekend-empire?newsfeed=true |title=Radio 1's Hackney Weekend offers an urban alternative to the Olympics |newspaper=The Observer |publisher=Guardian Media Group |date=23 June 2012 |accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref> **11 July – [[Chris Moyles]] announces on-air that he will leave the ''[[Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' in September. It is confirmed later the same day that he will be succeeded by [[Nick Grimshaw]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Crookes |first=Del |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/18792684 |work=Newsbeat |title=Chris Moyles to leave Radio 1 breakfast show in September |publisher=BBC |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> **14 September – Chris Moyles hosts his final breakfast show.<ref name=RadioToday-2012-08-06>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2012/08/date-set-for-new-radio-1-breakfast-show/ |title=Date set for new Radio 1 Breakfast show |publisher=Radio Today |date=9 August 2012 |accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref> **24 September – Nick Grimshaw takes over the ''[[Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]''.<ref name=RadioToday-2012-08-06/><ref>{{cite news|first=Elisabeth |last=Mahoney |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/24/nick-grimshaw-radio-1-breakfast-show?newsfeed=true |title=Nick Grimshaw's first Radio 1 breakfast show marks change of direction |newspaper=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian Media Group |date=24 September 2012 |accessdate=24 September 2012}}</ref>
*'''2013''' **January – A series of changes take place. These include the departure of [[Reggie Yates]] and [[Vernon Kay]]. [[Jameela Jamil]] is announced as the new presenter of ''[[The Official Chart]]'', [[Matt Edmondson]] is to host a weekend morning show and Tom Deacon will return to present a Wednesday night show. [[YouTubers]] [[Dan Howell]] and [[Phil Lester]] also join the station.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cairns |first=Dan |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/20267639 |title=BBC News – Vernon Kay and Reggie Yates to leave Radio 1 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref> **12 April – Radio 1 Controller [[Ben Cooper (media executive)|Ben Cooper]] announces that the station's ''[[Radio 1 Chart Show]]'' will not air "[[Ding-Dong! The Witch Is Dead]]", a song which charted following an internet campaign in the wake of the [[Death and funeral of Margaret Thatcher|death]] of former Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] on 8 April. Instead a portion of the song will air as part of a news item.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-21241791 |work=BBC News |title=R1 Chart show will not play full Margaret Thatcher song |publisher=BBC |date=12 April 2013 |accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref> **September – [[Tim Westwood]] leaves.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://wwwnews.live.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/23466305 | work=BBC News | title=Tim Westwood to leave Radio 1, 1Xtra | date=26 July 2013 | accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref>
*'''2014''' ** 17 February – [[Sara Cox]] hosts her last show for the station, who leaves to go back to [[BBC Radio 2]]. **7–8 March – Radio 1 marks [[International Women's Day]] with two nights of an all-female line-up from 7{{nbsp}}pm to 7{{nbsp}}am, featuring presenters including [[Annie Nightingale]] and [[Adele Roberts]]. The second night is also aired on [[BBC Radio 1Xtra|1Xtra]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/01/radio-1-1xtra-go-all-female-all-night/ |title=Radio 1 & 1Xtra go all female all night |publisher=Radio Today |date=15 January 2014 |accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> **September – A series of changes sees many notable presenters leave the station, including [[Edith Bowman]], [[DJ Nihal|Nihal]] and [[Rob da Bank]]. [[Huw Stephens]] gains a new show hosting 10{{nbsp}}pm{{snd}}1{{nbsp}}am Monday{{ndash}}Wednesday with Alice Levine presenting weekends 1{{nbsp}}pm{{snd}}4{{nbsp}}pm. Radio 1's Residency is also expanded with Skream joining the rotational line-up on Thursday nights 10{{nbsp}}pm{{snd}}1{{nbsp}}am.
*'''2015''' **25 January – [[Clara Amfo]] takes over as presenter of ''[[The Official Chart]]''. **27 February – [[Fearne Cotton]] announces she is to leave Radio 1 to start "a new chapter".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/31660977 |title=Fearne Cotton is leaving Radio 1 and having another baby |publisher=BBC |work=BBC Radio 1 |date=27 February 2015 |accessdate=27 February 2015}}</ref> **5 March – [[Zane Lowe]] presents his final show. **24 March – Radio 1 announces that ''[[The Official Chart]]'' will move from Sundays to Friday afternoons from mid-July in response to changes in the day new music is released.<ref>{{cite news|first=Mark |last=Savage |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-32019327 |title=Radio 1 chart show moving to Friday afternoons |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=24 March 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> **June – Schedule changes at Radio 1 and [[BBC 1Xtra]] see [[Adele Roberts]] presenting the Early Breakfast Show, replacing [[Gemma Cairney]]. Cairney will become the station's social action presenter, hosting ''[[The Surgery]]'' and documentaries for both networks.<ref>{{cite news|last=Eames |first=Tom |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a642027/ex-big-brother-star-adele-roberts-to-host-early-breakfast-show-on-bbc-radio-1.html#~pa2EQpqsMLjtA3 |title=Ex-Big Brother star Adele Roberts to host early breakfast show on BBC Radio 1 |publisher= |work=Digital Spy |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> **5 July – The final Sunday broadcast of Radio 1's ''[[The Official Chart]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-33400359 |title=Lionel Richie storms album chart |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=5 July 2015 |accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> **10 July – The first Friday broadcast of Radio 1's ''[[The Official Chart]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-33475265 |title=Ed Sheeran and David Zowie top UK's first Friday pop charts |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=10 July 2015 |accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> The programme is broadcast on Fridays as part of the drive time show, hosted by [[Greg James (DJ)|Greg James]]. The programme's airtime is almost halved, to just 1 hour 45 minutes with only the top 10 now being played in full.
*'''2016''' **No events.
*'''2017''' **30 September – Radio 1 celebrates its 50th birthday. Commemorations include a three-day pop-up station ''Radio 1 Vintage'' celebrating the station's presenters, and special on-air programmes on the day itself, including a special breakfast show co-presented by the station's launch DJ [[Tony Blackburn]], which is also broadcast on [[BBC Radio 2]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-41451898|title=DJs celebrate 50 years of Radio 1 and 2|date=30 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=14 July 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> **6 November – Radio 1 experiences schedule changes. A new weeknight show is launched: ''The 8th'', presented by [[Charlie Sloth]], broadcast on Radio 1 and sister station [[1Xtra]]. Other changes involve [[MistaJam]], Danny Howard, [[Katie Thistleton]], [[Huw Stephens]] and [[Phil Taggart]]. Kan D Man, DJ Limelight and Rene LaVice join.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/41508629/charlie-sloth-gets-new-late-night-entertainment-show-on-radio-1-and-1xtra|title=Charlie Sloth gets new late night entertainment show on Radio 1 and 1Xtra - BBC Newsbeat|date=10 May 2017|website=BBC Newsbeat|language=en-GB|access-date=4 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/schedules/p00fzl86/2017/11/07|title=BBC Radio 1 - Schedules, Tuesday 7 November 2017|website=BBC|language=en-GB|access-date=4 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''2018''' **24 February – Radio 1 overhauls its weekend schedule. The changes see [[Maya Jama]] and [[Jordan North]] joining the network as weekend presenters, fronting the ''Greatest Hits'' programme, while current presenter [[Matt Edmondson]] moves to present a weekday afternoon show on which he will be joined by a different guest co-presenter each week. [[Alice Levine]] moves from afternoons to weekend breakfasts to co-present with [[Dev (DJ)|Dev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/42703116/maya-jama-and-celebrity-guests-join-radio-1-weekend-line-up|title=Maya Jama and celebrity guests join Radio 1 weekend line-up |work=BBC Radio 1 Newsbeat|date=17 January 2018|publisher=BBC|accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> **15 June – ***Radio 1 starts broadcasting much of its weekend schedule on Fridays meaning that the weekday daytime schedule is now only broadcast from Mondays to Thursdays. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2018/r1-weekend-friday|title=BBC – Weekend starts early on Radio 1 – Media Centre|website=www.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> ***[[Scott Mills]] replaces [[Greg James (DJ)|Greg James]] as host of ''[[The Official Chart]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/scott-mills-to-replace-greg-james-as-official-chart-host__22495/ |title=Scott Mills to replace Greg James as Official Chart host |date=10 April 2018 |publisher=The Official UK Charts Company |accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref> **9 August – [[Nick Grimshaw]] presents the ''[[Radio 1 Breakfast Show|breakfast show]]'' for the final time. **20 August – [[Greg James (DJ)|Greg James]] becomes the 16th person to present the ''[[Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2018/r1-breakfast|title=Nick Grimshaw and Greg James to swap Radio 1 shows |work=BBC Media Centre|publisher=BBC|date=31 May 2018|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/newsbeat-45244619 |title=Greg James's Radio 1 Breakfast: What we learned from the first show |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=20 August 2018 |accessdate=20 August 2018}}</ref> **3 September – [[Nick Grimshaw]] takes over as host of the drivetime show. Jack Saunders hosts a new show named 'Radio 1 Indie Show'. **9 September – [[Huw Stephens]]' [[BBC Introducing]] show moves to Sunday nights as part of a shake-up of the Sunday schedule.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-44479434|title=Radio 1 and 1Xtra announce new hosts|date=14 June 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=4 November 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> **3 October – [[Charlie Sloth]] announces he will leave Radio 1 and 1Xtra after ten years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/newsbeat-45741140 |title=Charlie Sloth to leave BBC Radio 1 and 1Xtra after nearly 10 years |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=3 October 2018 |accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref> **20 October – Having announced earlier in the month that he is leaving Radio 1 and BBC 1Xtra, Charlie Sloth now says this will happen with immediate effect. Previously he had been scheduled to leave in November.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/newsbeat-45927344 |title=Charlie Sloth: Radio 1 and 1Xtra DJ leaving station immediately |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=20 October 2018 |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> **26 October – Radio 1 announces a schedule change that will see [[Matt Edmondson]] and [[Mollie King]] co-presenting the ''[[Radio 1's Weekend Breakfast Show|Radio 1 Weekend Breakfast Show]]'', while [[Dev (DJ)|Dev]] and [[Alice Levine]] will move to weekend afternoons.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-45976649 |title=Matt Edmondson and Mollie King to host BBC Radio 1 weekend breakfast |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=26 October 2018 |accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox company | name = Universal Attractions, Inc. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = [[New York, New York]] (1949) | location = [[Midtown Manhattan]] (United States) | key_people = Jeff Allen, Co-Owner
Jeff Epstein, Co-Owner | website = http://www.universalattractions.com }} '''Universal Attractions Agency''' ('''UAA''') is an American talent agency. It was founded by Ben Bart in 1949. The [[New York City]]–based agency is currently under the management of Jeff Allen{{Cite web|url=http://www.celebrityaccess.com/news/profile.html?id=106|title=CelebrityAccess Industry Profiles|website=www.celebrityaccess.com|access-date=2016-04-10}} and Jeff Epstein. In business since 1949, UAA is located in New York City. The agency’s history includes launching the career of the soul singer [[James Brown]] and representing him for more than 40 years.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} ==History== In 1949, agent Ben Bart decided to resign from his position at The Gale Agency. He opened the Universal Attractions Agency that same year.http://www.doowopcafe.net/Ravens.html{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/james-brown/biography|title=James Brown Biography|website=Rolling Stone}} ==Notable past artists== [[Jimmy Lunceford]]
